Home Mush Mush Advice Ask the SDF! #3
This discussion has been marked as resolved (or the issue has been well-discussed).
On may 2, 2015
[7950824]

Hello mushlings, and welcome to the third iteration of this thread! This post and thread should help clarify what is reportable/sanctionable or not. If you have any questions regarding the rules or which behaviour you could report, please, ask here.

If you have a question regarding a sanction you've received or wish to speak to us personally, send us a message.

Rules of English Mush


When reporting rule breaking on your ships, please, you must type in a reason for the report! In If you leave it blank, the judges have to pick through the whole ship's logs to find out what went on.

We've found a glitch in reports where a reported private message of any kind (to your self, blank or with others) will send in a blank report. We have the logs but the judges don't know why the report was made so it's very important that we do not report private messages of any kind, find a random post in main chat to report, if you have to. Do not report PMs. We'll let you know when this is fixed!

In addition, do not just type, "Griefer". More information will only help us.


Anonymity
Many find anonymity to be one the best features of this game and choose to keep anonymity at all times. There is no Twinoid fame in Mush, no long time member hero worship and you are free to role play the character you've chosen without anyone knowing who you really are. Because most of us do want to keep our anonymity and not know the identity of others on our ships, we strongly suggest everyone preserve anonymity because it's more enjoyable to play that way.


Spreadsheets, other tools, and external communication
We won't be sanctioning for spreadsheet use. That said, there will plenty of time for total organization in private ships when they come. Spreadsheet encouragement on public ships is often futile as not everyone will use them and remember, the mush can see them as well and destruction of important documents is a valid mush strategy. Lists can also lead to tensions as the super organized might pressure the under organized. You can post your link once and please, don't expect new players or those who would rather stay in game to use these tools.

A note on IRC use - while it's very convenient its use is discouraged on public ships. No one will be sanctioned for using it nor scolded on the forums (/me puts his whip away) it must be used very carefully. IRC logs cannot be used to contest a sanction because like screenshots, they can be tampered with. All pertinent information gleaned from an IRC conversation must be summarized in game. This is the only way for the SDF to see the evidence of the ship's happenings.


Inactivity or Idlers
Inactivity (new players, players not communicating or playing) will not be sanctioned, do not report them. We do not want to sanction new players who might not be engaged. Learning to work around these players is part of our game. You *can* succeed on as ship that has many deaths and/or a fair number of inactive players. Luck and team work amongst those left will be in order but it can be done. Thoughtful communication and patience can go a long way.

There are a couple, very specific, instances of inactivity or perceived inactivity which can be reported. If there is proof of idling for XP farming without actually playing, this can be reported. Proof though would include an admission of this type of activity. Widespread idling for XP gain isn't happening and it shouldn't be assumed that someone inactive is engaging in this activity. Over reporting this will result in a sanction for the unnecessary reports if there isn't solid proof of this behaviour.

The other type of inactivity that can be reported is surrender or giving up. For example, a player has had a disagreement on the ship and stops playing. This is not allowed, ships must be played out.


Ships filling slowly, and Neutral Play
There will be the rare times ships might take longer to fill, when this happens we will expect "neutral play". Which means, we don't do anything that specifically will help either team. As an example, killing hunters is acceptable as a mush goal can potentially be to live longer as much as it is a human goal. What's not acceptable is holding the wrench, apron, weapons and other critical items prior to Mush selection; and you may be sanctioned if found doing so. These items may be moved, but not kept in your inventory. We consider holding onto items in order to have an advantage after Mush selection as a violation of Neutral Play.

The main point of Neutral Play is to give neither side a distinct advantage at the moment of Mush selection. If you have both blasters, and you are selected as Mush, it gives you and your team a significant advantage. The same can be said if you are selected as human. A griefer could pick up critical items before Mush selection, then hold onto them; this gives them a personal advantage, but more importantly, you'll probably have to kill them in order to get those items back. It is better (at the very least, it makes for a more interesting game) for neither side to have a distinct advantage after Mush selection, and that is why these Neutral Play rules exist.

Note: Neutral research before Mush selection IS allowed. Neutral research examples include - Ultra-healing Pomade or the NCC Lenses.

It is at the discretion of judges in this matter, if they feel the game has been spoiled for humans or Mush, they will give a sanction.

Mush Tests updated Jan 29/14
While Mush tests are allowed it is not just to kill someone who refuses to take one. The player might not have AP, might not want to be sick if the test would make them so or the player might just not want to partake in the test because they don't like them. Refusing to do the test alone is not a valid reason to kill someone. If this is the only evidence you have that someone is Mush, it's not enough and could be seen as an unjustified killing which will net a sanction.

Communicate, Communicate, Communicate!
This isn't a rule, per se, but it's crucial to the success of any ship. As simple as it sounds, following this bit of advice is something that may keep you alive longer. As a social game, other players are dependent upon you for information. People who wander around and don't communicate are often the first to be suspected of being Mush. Note that they're usually the first to be assassinated. Communicate more, and you have an easier time earning the trust of your shipmates...and trusted people are less likely to be killed over a misunderstanding!

Remember, Mush is a teamwork game! You can't actively work against your team be it mush or human! If you play as a human and you sabotage the humans (killing for no reason relate to the advancement of the human cause, taking both showers apart, cooking all the rations and letting them spoil, etc) this is griefing and it will be taken very seriously. If you are mush, you cannot denounce your fellow mush or impede the mush cause, you must work as a team.

Have fun!
Mush mods. Peanutz, Impet and spacekadt
in fond memory, Annette and Spazticus$6826491

On may 2, 2015
[7950824]

I can't sticky. A moddier mod than I might do so when convenient, but this thread was asked for. I do what I can. Don't make me Snape anyone!


[...] Is occupaing of the Medlab bed before mush selection ON PURPOSE griefing? Crewmate is online, chatting, but dont leave the bed. All crew beed operations. Or is it another way to heal broken finger/nose/etc

If the intention is to grief, yes, if not, usually not. It's a hard call. Ideally, talk to the player, ask them to stand up, maybe someone on the ship early can post a reminder about injuries, medlab, and needing the bed.

Few things to consider - no starting injury (that I know of) is lethal over time. Some are very annoying, but none have to be fixed immediately. Thus is can be possible to just wait a few cycles, then get it fixed. We may *want* to fix that injury RIGHT NOW, but it's not a real need.

Solid and wrestler can throw someone out of a room even before mush selection, thus it may be possible to clear the bed without needing cooperation, if really desired.

On may 3, 2015
[7950824]

Perhaps the safest way would be say, if there were four mush, and one of them known by the other mush to be a once a day player or something.

I'd make the plan without even involving that 4th rarely active mush, with the other three. All three of us already has the 'welcome back' spore ready; the anti-cure gets used on the offline uninformed dude, then the real cure (We are thinking like mush, right?) readministered in the middle of the 4th mush's inactive period, so for that player there was never even a second when they knew they were human (or even knew they were going to become human). That way the 4th mush is also completely in the cure, if ever reported. The judges would see the logs that they were not aware of what was going to happen, so there is 0% chance that they failed to play for the human team during that instant before they became mush again.

That is not to say that an informed 4th mush would be in trouble - but the area gets more and more gray the more information and power that targeted mush has to take action.
On may 3, 2015
sperbi

well, theoretically as long as that person is a mush, the person can prepare everything to not be able to do anything when being a human. For example drop the walkie talkie in another room, being without any energy or mp at the time the cure shoudl happen.
And at that time of the curing the mushes are very quickly spiking him, before a real human is coming and able to check the skills, so even with whispering the humans can't be informed.

On may 3, 2015
Chime

You can report anyone you want - if just doesn't have the effect you want in most cases.
(And creates more work for the judges).

If your name was used in the context of bashing/attacking you personally it should count under Rudeness, insults and work. But just figuring out who you are isn't exactly harming you, no? If they have a bad opinion of you might actually change it there.

Picking ones skills is up to oneself but if she doesn't pick shrink to actively harm you and you can prove it that works too. If she for example openly states that she's not taking shrink because she wants to make the trip harder for anyone...
On may 3, 2015
Kyubey

Can we report someone who don't want to choose a viral passive skill that'll help humans in Pre-Mush selection ?
Before mush selection nobody can force anyone to do anything.
- You can take Pilot and choose not to shoot any hunters before mush selection
- You can take Tech and refuse to dismantle shower before mush selection
- You can refuse to take Shrink or stay out of dorms
- You can choose not to install cameras as Paranoid
Yes, those actions will hurt humans, but you are not playing human yet, you are waiting for game start.

After mush selection, every player should do everything to help your team, but his way of helping team can be not-standart. For example - if bronze Raluca thinks that taking Genius and getting CS in 1 min after selection is the best way to play, you can disagree with her, but it's not a reason to report. But if there is no reason to choose unpopular skill other then hurt the team - it is.
On may 4, 2015
Morgaine

You can take Pilot and choose not to shoot any hunters before mush selection

One ship, hull was down to under 80 because pilots refused to deal with hunters until everyone awoke.

Flash

It's one of the oversights by the guy who did the web development for the english site. I don't think it'll ever get fixed. As a workaround you can put a link to your 'My Account', 'Forum', etc. on the Twinoid shortcut bar ( http://twinoid.com/user/customizeBar ) and click those instead.

If you go to the forums while you are not on a ship, you will be taken to a familiar page. It is not necessary to join a ship to get past the home page; I hover over my upper right corner name and click on a followed forum link that was recently updated to get around that.
On may 29, 2015
[1195601]

Is it a vailid mush strategy to convert someone and take anonymush right before killing them, so that humans think that they're mushfree or to divert suspicion from yourself?
On may 29, 2015
sperbi

If it helps the mush cause, it is valid.
That is vague, right? Well it is!
If the person is rather inactive and probably no help as mush and your plan seems sneaky enough, it is a good strategy.
If you are killing a very active potential mush fellow with it and you aren't very good in making the humans to believe that you killed the last mush it is more playing against your team and a bad strategy.
So all in all it is valid (unless it is obvious to humans you converted the person before killing them). But be careful with it, it could end as a double-edged sword.
On may 29, 2015
1412

Yeah, you need to have a good reason to kill them. If it seems like too much f a coincidence, they might get suspicious.
On may 30, 2015
kreton

If the person is inactive it's okay. If you just transformed and right afterwards killed an active player without his okay, it's aginst the rules.
On may 30, 2015
Kyubey

Don't confuse others, kreton
Communication is an important part of the game, but you never need anyone's approval, if you are sure, that thing you are doing is better for the team.
You can kill a player of your team, if it's best thing to do in your situation, while his opinion is irrelevent.
You can kill a player, others don't want you to kill, if you are sure, that you are right, and others are wrong.
And so on.

http://mush.twinoid.com/theEnd/7472 for example, where killing an active mush as a mush without asking, got mushes a victory
On may 30, 2015
kreton

I am very sure that there was a Discussion in the Forum about this once and it was said that throwing a mush without his approval under the bus would be aginst the rule. I could be wrong of course but I am very sure.
On may 30, 2015
sperbi

I think that problem is rather a question of:
"Is it wise to turn a person and kill that person afterwards?"
Especially when it is an active person, it is mostly not wise. so much effort to get that person, so much potential, loosing of fun while trying to plan schemes with the potential fellow, always making someone feel a bit bad (at least I always don't like to get killed )... common sense would tell you in most cases that it is not a good idea to to convert and kill an active person.
But you can't always put an absolute statement here.
For example if you are on a ship with only active ppl (or inactive ones died quickly), if you want to get an infiltration an active mush needs to die somehow.
In many cases it might be better to discuss it with the mush first, so the mush can do a rampage, sabotage, whatever before getting killed.
Converting and active person and killing the person afterwards is very difficult to pull off so it is furthering the mush cause, that is the problem. Infecting an active person is difficult, having a reason to kill a that active person (why do you suddenly think the person is mush???) is an even bigger problem-if I see someone killing a mush without understanding it how he get to that knowledge, I would kill the killer too...
And not being able to use the knowledge/connections of the active person or rather wasting them, is that really worth it? Well, sometimes it might be worth it, only in very few cases...
I think ppl are rather thinking about that tactic who don't trust their fellows very much and are very interested to not die themselves/sacrifice themselves.
On may 30, 2015

On may 30, 2015
Dzanek

About killing Mush partner without asking:

You can't kill your partner if it isn't suspicious enough and crew aren't demanding its die. You can't even kill when your partner is a smart person who has the plan how to convert or kill the crew.

But you can kill your partner when logs revealed the Mush and inactive ones, it's obvious. You can even kill it when it's too suspicious because of:Taking the Soap without report of being dirty, being quiet since Mush selection in the public chat when in the Mush one seems to tell more, holding the apron, going thorugh Bravo Dorm without reason too often, reporting getting hurt upon picking up the Soap, etc. and crew is about to kill him and you can't believe that your partner would survive the ship. When your partner doesn't listen to your warnings - you can kill the Mush.
It happened to me 13 of 16 times as Alpha Mush to get such partner, however, I haven't killed them, but could...

But remember, that killing Mush partner must aim to gain more trust and make crew not suspect you.

I never did it though, as I wasn't sure whether it was allowed or not.

On may 30, 2015
spacekadt
Bobik42Is it a vailid mush strategy to convert someone and take anonymush right before killing them, so that humans think that they're mushfree or to divert suspicion from yourself?

To answer the original question accurately:

You may kill a newly turned mush immediately if it helps the mush team. The basic strategy goes along the lines of "convert, take anon, kill new mush, now there are no mush in the crew bar and no more suspicion".

This should be someone that's been somewhat suspicious, otherwise, you're going to get a lot of questions about how you knew that person was mush and probably won't achieve your end goal.

This all pretty much needs to be done within about 5 minutes, generally. To convert someone and let them live for any amount of time turns the scenario into playing against your team.
On may 31, 2015
[6826491]

Spacey has the correct answer on this one. Even if the player is active, if it's done immediately, and in a way that helps the Mush team, it's acceptable.

That does not mean that it's an ideal strategy for every ship, if done this way. But it IS acceptable.

On may 31, 2015
spacekadt
NGJon

That seems a little overpowered on random ships with loads of inactive... how do mush ever lose in that case?
(oh noes i have an inactive mush partner, oh well, i'll convert this inactive , kill them both and just wait till the ship blows up or we go to sol.....good thing eleesha is the least favourite character so is usally taken by inactives...)

and to think i've been playing as a mush in ships where humans had a 'chance'

Mostly, time. You can only infect once per day and you're going to get dirty doing it. The constant dirty plus just happening to know who the mush were with no valid leads is going to keep you pretty high on the list of suspects. That's why it pretty much only works with actives that are suspicious for whatever reason.
On may 31, 2015
Kyubey

actives that are suspicious
Well using skills like Defractor you can always blame others in same room, even if they were trusted humans before.
When humans see the situation like:
- In room X defractor was used
- Mush was kill in room X
- His killer claim to be dirty from killing
It will cause you no trouble.

Best targets for such tactics are humans with 'dangerous' skills. If you don't really need them to be mushes, you just want them to be killed and then lie low - it's a good way to make your life much easier. Chao with Torture, Eleesha with Tracker.

I have been praised for using this method. I have never heard of a rule against it. And believe it is approved by the SDF. I am not an expert though.
On june 1, 2015

On june 1, 2015
Kyubey

This method have a lot of flaws. You can use it ofc, but it's very-very far from ideal method to win most of games.
On june 1, 2015
DarkTheRaven

There's no rule against doing so, however if you play an entire game without even attempting anything you could be frowned upon by players
On june 1, 2015
[1820396]

The flaw of this method is that humans can't return to Sol (or even go to Eden) before two mushes are dead. Doing so would be basically surrender, because then they know they have mush on board and returning to Sol means they are deliberately losing a game.

So this method has some sense only in situations when your partner alone (you're trying to pass for human so you'll have probably no way to help him, remember) will be able to infect some other character so you can take anonymush.
This is by no means foolproof plan. Active human Eleesha can check for the printability of The List, someone can get lucky and notice that there are three mushes at the moment between infection and taking of anonymush and you can still be outed by things like not getting jumpkin head when eating one or not eating any at all, although you're for some reason expected to do so and wouldn't have reason to not eat one as a human.

Playing as a human is much better used in preparation of some mushy plan like rampage at suitable moment, Pilgred rush and hacking of command or something like that. And those plans can be stopped by active human at the right (or rather wrong) moment.
On june 1, 2015
[6826491]
Patches1984The flaw of this method is that humans can't return to Sol (or even go to Eden) before two mushes are dead. Doing so would be basically surrender, because then they know they have mush on board and returning to Sol means they are deliberately losing a game.

I can't stress this enough. You as a Mush can initiate the Sol return, of course, but a human can't. For the human team, it is sanctionable to return when you are 100% positive that there are living Mush on the crew bar, or when you know that Eleesha still has the option to print the List. Any human who initiates a return like this knowingly, should definitely be reported. We treat returning like this as a Harmful Return, because the human team hasn't satisfied the basic conditions for victory (returning without any Mush aboard.)

Note that if Eleesha is no longer alive, or has already printed the List, and any remaining Mush are Anonymush, it probably does NOT count as a Harmful Return for the humans.
On june 1, 2015
wLink
Patches1984The flaw of this method is that humans can't return to Sol (or even go to Eden) before two mushes are dead. Doing so would be basically surrender, because then they know they have mush on board and returning to Sol means they are deliberately losing a game.

But I meant trying to remain covered till Daedalus will get destroyed, and that will happen on any ship if they don't return to Sol or travel to Eden. I just used wrong words apparently.
On june 1, 2015
NERON

Rules in a nutshell : if you think it helps you win, do it

On june 1, 2015
[1820396]
WeakestLinkBut I meant trying to remain covered till Daedalus will get destroyed, and that will happen on any ship if they don't return to Sol or travel to Eden. I just used wrong words apparently.

Then you're just hoping that the other 13 non-mush people won't all get ill, won't be forced by circumstances to foodtest or eat jumpkin or won't die before the inevitable destruction. That can look easy on half inactive random ship, but on anything more active that's actually quite hard to pull off. People will count when you should starve, count your APs, telling you to eat or propose to bring you food when you say you're out of APs and then checking if you were able to do additional work. Especially when the ship starts to fall apart and everyone will be expected to the maximum for survival.
All this is avoidable and in the end there's a chance for victory, but it's by no means "guaranteed win".
On june 1, 2015
NERON

That is irrelevant. This is about the rules
Whether its a wise strategy or not, he is free to do it as long as it's intended to work towards his goals. This has a chance of succeeding, however small
On june 1, 2015
kreton
NERONRules in a nutshell : if you think it helps you win, do it

That's just wrong.
On june 1, 2015
NERON

1412

On june 1, 2015
NERON
Chime^Still not working. Admitting you yourself are mush is not encouraging others to play against their team. Randomly killing people isn't encouraging others either.

That's not usually helping you win though, which is the first point

One time, I did out myself in the chat in a situation that helps my team; It became obvious that exactly 3 people in the room that I occupied was mush. One was a partner that the humans were aware of; one was a human n00b that I convinced them were mush; that left me and one other, both were mush, but the humans thought it was only one of us and didn't know which. I outted because it was more useful to the team if the humans thought the mush was me for sure rather than shut us both out for being ambiguous. He infiltrated their hunting channel, while I was free to assist the other partner that was already outted.

Anyhow, the revision should be :
- Actions must be in the benefit of your team, as long as you think it is so
- You must not violate neutral play
- You must not compel others to break the above rules
On june 5, 2015
wLink

Are natamy rifle tests allowed?
On june 5, 2015
NERON

Nope. You're supposed to use the natamy on people you had the intent to kill for being mush initially. You cannot shoot people without proof in order to generate proof
On june 5, 2015
[6826491]
WeakestLinkAre natamy rifle tests allowed?

No. They are forbidden for testing purposes. If you have enough evidence to justify an assassination, then you're allowed to use the Natamy Rifle for it. That's what it's for. Assassinations. NOT testing.

We've had to take this stance, because the Natamy Rifle can deal up to three injuries per hit, and two shots can kill a Gold human. Furthermore, people were randomly shooting people with it, in hopes of catching a Mush. This is unacceptable, and does not suffice for an "investigation." The damage dealt and AP required for surgery afterward does not justify the means used.
On june 5, 2015
Morgaine
WeakestLinkAre natamy rifle tests allowed?

I do not like Natamy. One casting ship, we used it as a test and went through almost all the crew (luckily we had a medic aboard). Without a medic, if you are wrong, then you consign your ship to failure as injuries are a right pain to fix by self-surgery (maybe a day's worth of actual ap or more to heal, and if you have multiple walking wounded requiring medlab bed...) The natamy rifle is best used to kill a mush. I suppose if you are 100% it is either A or B, but cannot decide which one it is, then maybe, I guess.
On june 5, 2015
Dzanek

The Natamy Rifle is better than Blaster even against humans because of higher risk of making injuries. Mush can take it for a rampage and make huge damage with this (especially shooters).

I still remember my seemingly Mush-free ship. 2 Mush dead, PILGRED repaired, and I didn't like Eleesha who was so quiet in the beginning and then she became to be more talkative. Crew even demanded her to take Medic Mage Book in order to help in some research. What did I do? I made Natamy Rifle and shot her face in the "Mush-free ship" and the next dead Anonymush in the comrade bar. Still remember commander's words:
Holy s***nuggets!
On june 5, 2015
Kyubey

Well, Natami is good way to pardon a crewmember , who you have decided to kill. If you have started the assasination, and he survived 2 shoots, you can stop (or better 2 shoots with a punch).
You can say, that rule about natami is something like - "Don't shoot anyone with natami, if you don't want him to die and don't have reason to kill him.".
On june 5, 2015
DarkTheRaven

The rule to my understanding is if you don't have genuine reason to suspect the person don't even touch the trigger
On june 5, 2015
[6826491]
KyubeyWell, Natami is good way to pardon a crewmember , who you have decided to kill. If you have started the assasination, and he survived 2 shoots, you can stop (or better 2 shoots with a punch).
You can say, that rule about natami is something like - "Don't shoot anyone with natami, if you don't want him to die and don't have reason to kill him.".

But that still makes it sound like we condone Natamy testing, Kyubey - and we can't do so in good conscience. People will just say, "I didn't want to kill them, I wanted to clear them." Ultimately, it's still a Natamy test.

That's why the rule is, "If you already have enough evidence to justify killing that player, then you can use it for the assassination, as a human. Otherwise, you potentially risk being sanctioned."

I'll also grant that if you already have enough evidence to justify the assassination, you fire twice, and they don't die after two hits, you probably should stop, and hope you have a Medic to heal them immediately.
On june 5, 2015
Kyubey

I'm just saying you have an option to stop after you already agreed to kill.
If my previous post is not clear:
- Don't shoot a person, if you don't have a reason to kill him
- Don't shoot a person, if you have a reason to suspect him, but did not agree, that kiiling him is best option already

So I totally agree with this one:
"If you already have enough evidence to justify killing that player, then you can use it for the assassination, as a human. Otherwise, you potentially risk being sanctioned."
Natami is the same weapon as blaster or knife for this rule.

Still:
- I prefer natami over any other weapon to kill a suspect - if he is mush it take much less ap, if he is human, it gives him some chances to survive
- I don't think you need Medic at all for killing a person with natami. If he happen to survive shoots - he can go and heal himself. If he dies - well, you already were ok with that.
On june 6, 2015
npfan
SpazticusI'll also grant that if you already have enough evidence to justify the assassination, you fire twice, and they don't die after two hits, you probably should stop, and hope you have a Medic to heal them immediately.KyubeyIf my previous post is not clear:
- Don't shoot a person, if you don't have a reason to kill him
- Don't shoot a person, if you have a reason to suspect him, but did not agree, that kiiling him is best option already
...
Still:
- I prefer natami over any other weapon to kill a suspect - if he is mush it take much less ap, if he is human, it gives him some chances to survive
- I don't think you need Medic at all for killing a person with natami. If he happen to survive shoots - he can go and heal himself. If he dies - well, you already were ok with that.

Something to keep in mind though that it is possible to prove someone is human after one shot. Before surgery is performed, anyone can use the Medikit and you'll get proven human, proven Mush, or inconclusive. Someone with Medic on a ship without Ultra-Healing Pomade or anyone without Medic on a ship with Ultra-Healing Pomade can eliminate the inconclusive possibility. That said, the Natamy Rifle should only be used with the intent to kill, but you might be able to save someone if you happen to get enough evidence your target is human.

On june 21, 2015
spacekadt

Tech would have been better than physicist. Physicist is good for one project and for pilgred, either of which is helped just as much by tech - with the exception of the daily pilgred point which is negligible.

There's no skill that's *forbidden* to copy. But your motivations are what matter. If you're taking something that you're well aware isn't useful or optimal then you're opening yourself up for a sanction. If you think you're doing what's best for the ship, you're probably fine.

it's not about "doing sub-optimal choices" but about "willingly hurt your team"

for exemple you can't be punished by SDF for picking a skill, unless it is clearly stated somewhere that you did it to hurt your team

Aceb

Surely you can! You always can report if you think that there was rule breaking event/words.
On june 23, 2015
spacekadt

Basic swearing as a result of frustration is definitely not sanctionable. SDF is not anyone's mother and isn't here to make sure your delicate eyes and ears aren't offended.

Swearing that rises to the level of harassment or otherwise breaks the sites T&C is generally sanctionable and should be reported.

Someone saying "mush bitch" because they're frustrated that you just. won't. die. is not going to be sanctioned if that's all they did.
On june 23, 2015
NERON

On june 23, 2015
Interrobang

Is buying a food item from the Vending Machine and holding onto it pre-mush reportable or is it considered a "Personal Item?" It just came up on my ship that someone could possibly pay to clear themselves, and I find that troubling.

I would assume it's possible to buy consumables before mush selection without a drawback for this reason. I guess I hadn't really thought about this before.
On june 23, 2015
spacekadt

I can't imagine any judge or mod deciding that something you buy with real actual money is anything other than a personal item. If you buy food from the vending machine and want to hold on to it, you're fine.

However, the only way to *prove* yourself that way is to have a full inventory when buying it so it knocks over into the room. Otherwise, there's no way to prove you didn't buy it before selection or get someone to give you theirs to drop or something. Since I generally hate proofs, if I'm buying vending machine food, I'll do it with room in my inventory so I don't knock it over.
On june 23, 2015

I would assume it's possible to buy consumables before mush selection without a drawback for this reason. I guess I hadn't really thought about this before.

Any items you brought from machine are your personal.

[6826491]
NERON

Pre-selection, Raluca takes the medlab bed. People ask her to leave because of surgeries. She comes online and replies "Raluca : I would just sleep a little...", everyone involved (Raluca, people in need of surgery, medic) then proceeds to stay in the medlab for many cycles, even into mush selection

Tough call. The people who need surgery generally need surgery, ASAP, and it's not good to hog the medlab bed, potentially preventing that from happening. At the very least, it's an easy way to lead to an early morale death for Raluca, if you don't have a Solid or Wrestler to kick her out of the bed (pre-selection.) To do so intentionally is bad gameplay at best, and passive negativity at worst, especially if the player has been around long enough to reasonably know better.

NERON

Sorry for double post ... this is an eventful ship

Reportable? Legal to cure with RFS?

VERY reportable. Mush are never allowed to request the RFS, as it is treated as a surrender. Nor may they "bargain" for it by claiming that they "didn't kill anyone." So not only did they NOT do their utmost as a Mush, they're playing against their team by surrendering to be cured.

Players who do this not only deserve to be reported and sanctioned, they also deserve to be killed for it. Don't reward them for surrendering.

Sort of related to this, but at what point should we be reporting players for breaking neutral play? For example, I've noticed a lot of players making themselves dirty before mush selection. There are legitimate reasons (dismantling, self-surgery, etc) but what if they refuse to shower until the ship fills? What if they won't say how they were dirty? Also, what about people who take up beds in the dorms and lie down for 6-7 cycles?

On june 26, 2015
[8200803]

This shouldn't even be a question. The intent is obvious.

On june 26, 2015
[6826491]
PatrykSzczescieAbout 1. - some rumors say that Mush are selected if ship isn't filling for long days. If it's right, when is the neutral play over?

This is true, and it's D4C1, if the ship isn't full by that point.
About 7. - Can you really make Rocket Launcher after shower gets dismantled?One COULD do that, but doing so would very likely lead to being reported as playing against the team. Just because one CAN do something does not mean that they should. About Mycoscan, once Spazticus told it's allowed to make because it's so slow to make and possibly hurt a bit human team because of wasting tons of AP for it, is it true? Yes. Most crews won't do it, but it's not an explicit violation of Neutral play. Usually people prefer to save their AP for the direct anti-Mush research, but the reason I believe it doesn't require the Mush Sample is even simpler than that: If the ship is very slow to fill, the crew might want to start expos - and they'd need to know if they've been spored by a Mush Trap.Can you install cameras in storages or dismantle the shower in Bravo Dorm?You can, and that is NOT a violation of Neutral Play. That is not to say that your crew will accept it, and they may put more suspicion on you...or be more likely to kill you for it. It is suspicious behavior, after all. Taking and holding onto them could be considered a Neutral Play violation, because you're denying anyone else the opportunity to place them. (Unless you're Gioele with his two Paranoid cameras. That particular case is a a bit more understandable, since the three cameras the ship starts with are still presumably available.)
On june 26, 2015
Kyubey
PatrykSzczescieAbout 1. - some rumors say that Mush are selected if ship isn't filling for long days. If it's right, when is the neutral play over?

Neutral play is over when mushes are selected. "After the last 16th player joins the ship" and "yellow icons" are mostly for new players, so they can easily spot the moment. Ofc if mushes were selected by time limit (D4 if I remember right) - then it's the end of neutral play.
About 7. - Can you really make Rocket Launcher after shower gets dismantled?
Can you install cameras in storages or dismantle the shower in Bravo Dorm?
You cannot make actions, that will clearly hurt human team, or just annoy everyone before you became a mush. Use common sence.
There is no rule, that you cannot do something unusual, like Rocket Launcher from first shower or Sofa in Icarus bay with camera. Just ask your team, if they want something like that.
About 12. (or 11.) - "you can kill him just before selection" - what?
Just after mush selection.

Kyubey- Eating bananas/alien fruits, when humans want to plant them is wrong

Kyubey- Dismantling objects, nobody wants to be dismantled is wrong (like second shower or tabulatrix)

Same. It's all about intent. Although, with this example, experienced players who should know better will not get away with actions like these just because they don't admit to trying to hurt the humans.

On june 30, 2015
Dzanek

Is it sanctionable if you try to kill Chun because she threatened to kill you?
On june 30, 2015
[6826491]
PatrykSzczescieIs it sanctionable if you try to kill Chun because she threatened to kill you?

Does she have sufficient evidence to suspect you? If she does, then killing her isn't going to help the ship. There are other things you can do, including proving yourself as human (naturally or by choice) that could alleviate or remove that suspicion.

Now, if you kill her because she is playing against the team, say, by accusing people without any evidence and then killing them, then it's a move intended to reduce the harm the random killings would cause, and that killing would be justifiable.

Don't go looking for a loophole here...if you've done things that are even remotely suspicious, then killing her would be even more suspicious.

On july 1, 2015
NERON

Chun is not god. The fact that many experienced players tend to avoid her leaves her more open to players of certain ... sketchyness

Over the 59 random ships I've played, I can recall 4 distinct Chuns who were similar to the one you mentioned : legitimately trying to play the game at first (not full-on 'MURICA griefer); but emotionally immature and egocentric, which leads her to end up doing more damage to the ship than good, sometimes unintentionally though bad decisions but also sometimes because she lost her temper and decided to go stabbing. This is all the while causing massive amounts of friction with the crew

In one case I led the crew to kill Chun (post-mush hunt, of course). She had done a laundry list of little things that messed up our game. It was so bad that we had to abandon the original hunt channel to exclude her and create a new anti-mush channel, which amusingly evolved into an anti-Chun channel. We put up with her during the hunt but after that was over, we had a long debate and vote. Although she had not acted with malicious intent (yet), we felt that her idea of what it meant to be on the human team was so wrong, we were much better off without her

As far as I know, no one other than possibly Chun got SDF points related to the incident, although I admit I was terrified to the point of composing a massive wall of text to post to the inbox just in caseMoral of the story : Chun is just another player. She may not be mush, but she can be incompetent, she can be a griefer, she can be a twelve year old. Use your judgement.
On july 1, 2015
Aceb

That's where "guilty beyond any doubts" come in.

I usually encourage people to report if they see rule breaker, but remember that Chun is always human and that most of players aren't aware of her action (she can't trust anyone at beginning, remember that).

If you see Chun going rampage, player is guilty.

If you see Chun killing a human or mush without any words or something, she probably have some reasons behind that alone/with mush hunters. If she kills again another human, you can probably report that or make some congratz claps to mushes.

On july 2, 2015
Chime

No. Whenever or not someone is guilty is not for us to judge. We're supposed to report those we believe to be breaking the rules so those handling these reports who are capable of checking what really happened can do the judging. That is how I understand it. And Aceb, what you've been saying so far sounds as if we're supposed to put Chun above any doubt simply because we can't know what's going on behind the scene. But it doesn't matter what is going on behind the scene:
If someone, anyone, Chun or not kills someone they ought to be able to state a reason for that deed. A mush of course has no reason to say "oh hey yeah I killed that dude 'cuz I'm mush" but if you assassinate someone because you think you found your mush in him. Or because they are a danger to the ship. You ought to have a reason and be able to explain your actions. Else the dead person might never understand what made them look so suspicious for you to mistake them as mush and the rest of the living crew will have to view you as a lose canon or griefer and act accordingly.

On july 2, 2015
[6826491]

To put this discussion to rest, if there is no stated reason for someone to be killed, and you believe it may have been random, report it.

If there IS a stated reason, but that reason seems to be a very weak justification, you can report it, too.

It doesn't matter if the reported person is Chun. Nobody is above suspicion, and even if someone isn't intending to break the rules, their actions may ultimately hurt the team. Mistakes can be made, for sure...but the SDF has the job of going through these reports to determine whether enough evidence to justify that killing exists. We'd rather you report a possible rule break, and we clear the accused, than to not have a report against someone, and they keep breaking the rules from game to game.

Morgaine

When I was 13 (a long time ago when computer games were loaded from cassette), I was really into Hammer Horror films. I had a television (black and white) in my room to watch them on a weekend night (R.I.P. Christopher Lee, such a talented man and not just for acting)

As for the 13+ on Mush I've only just noticed that! (Although I suppose it makes sense with DTT... not something I've broached with my son, but I have signed consent forms for education in school, oh, and he does find some of the coprolalia changes rather funny). Although I did know it was there for d2n, and made a parental judgement call for him to play it. However, maybe not necessarily for the content of the game, a concern I had was the language the other players use. OK, I do swear myself, even occasionally within earshot of my son, but when it is in game, I see no point in swearing via the keyboard. I can $*@? or just F!... instead.
One MMORPG I used to play, I wouldn't let my son anywhere near.. There was a 13 age limit, although younger players did sneak in. There was a bad-language filter so came out as **, but misspellings bypassed that and eventually, the filters were taken away. I haven't played that game since before the watchmen came out on d2n, but I still get junk/phishing emails wanting my account details for the MMORPG.

I'm actually glad I can make parental choice here, and I am glad there are moderators around, even to protect the adults as well as children from naughty players. For the Impire!

On july 2, 2015
[6826491]
Verenin other words you ask the SDF if that player is mush or no ?
because if they just look at it and don't quarantine him you'll know for sure he's mush
it's not the purpose of SDF and that's why they can't check unfinished ships

Actually, we can and do check ongoing ships. I personally checked on this ship in question, but we're not in the habit of publicly stating the results of any investigations. Sometimes we do, when it's a case of serial griefing...but don't expect us to reply.

Also, for those wondering, a sanction does not necessarily equal a quarantine, and on occasion, people get sanctioned for ships that ended a few weeks ago - so unless one is specifically informed by a mod, do not assume that a player is guilty of griefing on that particular ship.

- Ha-ha, I picked Shrink just to make game more difficult- then ye, that's reportable

On july 9, 2015
[1820396]
PatrykSzczescieCan you read Mage Book if your humanity isn't proven and the book is important? And what the crew can do for the person who for example read Shrink Mage Book in the ship where is no morale support? Or Technician where there's nobody able to repair PILGRED at more advance than 1%?

I don't think this is even something that should be asked SDF. Unless you're planning on being inactive or use that book for griefing or generally waste its potential (like reading pilot book when you're playing Paola, who needs to use all her APs for comms), I don't see any rules broken by reading a book by unconfirmed human.

Of course, another thing is not creating negative atmosphere by this action. It's good to discuss this beforehand, try to politely state your reasons for book being read by you and gain some support for that among the rest of the crewmembers.
On july 13, 2015
[8794477]

I know I have seen this answer before on the forums, but after about half an hour and many searches later, I still can't find it. So please forgive me asking again.

Re: Mush sleepers. Can a beta mush play exactly like a human (never spore, never infect/sabotage/break anything, etc) in order to help the crew reach Eden?

I'll list some proposed examples:

1. A beta that initially behaves mushy. After the Alphas are killed and he's not caught, goes to 'sleep' and plays exactly like a human in all ways to reach Eden. This one I think is actually probably allowed, but I list it so that we have a spectrum of behavior.

2. The second example is a beta that never got a chance to behave mushy (maybe they intended to, but the alphas died before they logged in, etc.) They then do the same - go to sleep.

3. A beta that makes this the strategy from the get go after taking anonymush and successfully evading detection.

I'm pretty sure 3 is not allowed, but am unsure about 2, and (as I said) I think #1 is allowed, as at human crew at least had a reasonable chance to prevent the Eden infection.
On july 13, 2015
sperbi

A beta mush trying to stay sneakily is always allowed if that is the intention of the mush team.
If the beta mush is just fully ignore them and not even speak with his alpha partners about the plan though the alphas actually need his help for another conversion, then that may be sanctioned-depending on circumstances and dependent on case to case.
But a mush infiltration is a legitimate mush strategy. Depending on the crew and activity it may even be rather difficult.
With a very active crew it is really hard to even accomplish that single beta mush without any noticing.
On july 13, 2015
Kyubey

Re: Mush sleepers. Can a beta mush play exactly like a human (never spore, never infect/sabotage/break anything, etc) in order to help the crew reach Eden?
You can, if using this strategy gives you reasonable chance to get to Sol/Eden undetected in any of cases you stated.

You cannot do it on ships, when this strategy will get you killed. If you get cured instead of killed, it's much worse fail btw. In these conditions trying to play as human can even earn you a report for surrendering:

- If humans are sure that there are mushes (Eleesha is active human with Tracker or logs of your convertion are visiable in modem)

- If humans suspect there are still mushes (alphas converted you using defractor in dorm duing day change, humans are not sure who exactly is beta, but think it's very likely one was made) and they have no emergecy to rush PILGRED (if humans suspect that there is a mush, but have no pilots and 30 hunters are following, maybe they'll have to rush PILGRED anyway - but it's unlikely for Eden ship)

P.s. A lot of players nowadays think, that doing nothing mushy is unbeatable, even for alpha-msuhes. They are very wrong. It's valid strategy only in some circumstance, that you/other mushes should create for you first. So it's no point to forbid it.
On july 13, 2015
[8794477]

Kyubey I started a much longer post, but this is 'Ask the SDF' and I don't want to hijack the thread. Will start a separate thread on on debating whether it should/should not be allowed. This thread is about whether is allowed.
On july 13, 2015
NERON

It's not a debate though.

Long story short, it's allowed if hiding and doing nothing mushy will help you win
If there is no way it leads to victory, it is not allowed

It's similar to foodtests : against some players' morals, not against SDF rules
On july 13, 2015
[8794477]

In ALL cases hiding leads to victory because the mush win by default. I'm not sure I'm following your answer...

On july 13, 2015
NERON

Yes, in the 3 cases you provided, the mush have a reasonable chance to win. All three are legal moves

Kyubey gave a few unrelated cases where the mush do not have a reasonable chance to win. Those are more in the grey
On july 13, 2015
Kyubey

Kyubey gave a few unrelated cases where the mush do not have a reasonable chance to win. Those are more in the grey
Ye, I just wanted to make sure, I don't mislead you into believing, that doing nothing mushy is always a good idea.

Short answer will be:
In all 3 cases it's allowed, it's irrelevant, if alpha-mushes are dead or alive
On july 13, 2015
[8794477]

Okay. I think I have processed what you two are trying to tell me.

If the humans are pretty sure they're mush free (beyond vague paranoia,) and are planing to bring PILGRED online for an Eden/Sol win, then it's permitted for mush to attempt 'sleeper mode.' Before this, the mush need to play mushy and be actively working toward (more or less) one of the other two mush victory conditions.

To restate it more succinctly: Once the mush can reasonably prove that humans are about to act to bring PILGRED online for a human win, 'sleeper mode' is allowed.

Is that a fair restatement of the policy?

Edit: Restated my restatement.
On july 13, 2015
[1820396]

I think you're still little bit off. Kyubey's examples, as I see them, are not so much about "what is or is not sanctionable" as about "what is or is not smart" (as Kobb very well pointed out in your other thread about this topic).

As a judge, I'd have pretty hard time to suggest a sanction for a reported player who just tried to play a stealth game by not infecting and not sabotaging. Unless he has openly denounced himself or directly stated to his partner(s) that he's not going to work with them as a mush, there's always possibility they were waiting for a good opportunity to strike and that opportunity just didn't come before they got uncovered. I was in this situation several times myself, so I can just sympathize with that.
On july 13, 2015
Kyubey

Kyubey's examples, as I see them, are not so much about "what is or is not sanctionable" as about "what is or is not smart"

It's very difficult to describe the line between doing not smart stuff and breaking rules in this situation...

For example:
- Good rampage is rampage that leave humans devastated, ship is destroyed
- Bad rampage could have a few kills, but humans were able to win after it - it's mush mistake, to think such rampage will work, but it was valid attempt
- But if mush just mutate with 5 ap, do 2 strikes and is killed - it can be seen as surrender/suicide, as it had no chances to begin with

Same here - there are situations, when acting like human is the best thing to do. Sometimes mushes try that and fail - it's ok too. But if it's oblivious, that trying to play human will only get you discovered and killed; then it's not right, to just delay the defeat, instead of using something else.
On july 13, 2015
[8794477]

Thank you all for your answers. I appear to have been mistaken before. It is not sanctionable to just play to exist and win by default if you're doing it with the purpose of a mush sol/eden return.

Is it true then that playing stealth (with no other goal in mind) just because you know the hunters will eventually hand you the win by default is not allowed - but would be nearly impossible to prove.
On july 13, 2015
Kenik

Actually that would be basically a slow burning rampage.
Your objective is to destroy the ship, you are just taking a reliable rout to it.
Rather than smashing obviously important equipment/crew.
On july 14, 2015
[8281990]

Frankly, a human team that loses that way was not a strong enough human team to deserve a win. They played a PvP game where one side effectively didn't show up, and they still lost.
On july 14, 2015
npfan
ZombieLawnGnomeIs it true then that playing stealth (with no other goal in mind) just because you know the hunters will eventually hand you the win by default is not allowed - but would be nearly impossible to prove.

That's a valid Mush strategy. The two main ways you can get sanctioned as a Mush is either you purposely sabotage your own team (e.g. out yourself, out your partners, etc.) or you give up without trying (e.g. you punch someone a couple of times expecting to get killed right after Mush selection). Any attempt to defeat the humans, passively or actively, is generally allowed.

On july 21, 2015
spacekadt

TBH - as a judge, one of the things I look for is "did it harm the ship and was there no possible benefit"

MT is notoriously trolly with things like mechanics of their games and what they do and don't encourage people to do. In the case of this Raluca, I wouldn't sanction her... but I also wouldn't sanction you for taking actions to prevent her from doing stuff like that again (assuming it's a pattern and not just a one time thing where a newbie is following instructions from the in-game tutorial and thinking she's helping).

That's *my* opinion. Others probably vary

On july 21, 2015

Kenik

On july 21, 2015
[8886413]

Question: If I am chun (who is always human) do I have to abide by Neutral play before mush selection?
On july 21, 2015
NERON

Yes, even Chun must follow neutral play
On july 21, 2015
[6826491]
Zazyman32Question: If I am chun (who is always human) do I have to abide by Neutral play before mush selection?

If she doesn't follow Neutral Play rules, then the game start is inherently biased against the Mush. Especially so if she hoards weapons and/or the armor pre-selection. That's why she's just as forbidden from holding any non-personal items before the ship fills as anyone else is.

Just as with anyone else, she is allowed to MOVE items to another room, but not HOLD them - at least not until the moment of selection.
On july 21, 2015
Kyubey

Neutral play is to make sure both teams has a chance to do everything, not to make sure humans can secure all items.

So Chun, holding grenade before selection and making sure no mush can use it without killing her is as bad as future-mush, who took grenade before selection - before anyone had chance to stop him.

You can place items you want to pick up in same room with you. You can pick them up in seconds after selection with any character, human or mush.
On july 26, 2015
[8794477]

New question: Is it permissible to put one short message into chat at the start of a ship. Something along 'OOC: Welcome, look forward to having fun with you on this ship... yadda yadda... if you like how I played, look us up and consider joining us!'
On july 26, 2015
[6826491]

Casting rules permit exactly ONE recruitment message per ship, so sure. The rest may be discussed in replies to that message, or in PMs.

NERON

First off, we killed one Alpha rather early, about 8 cycles after selection (although we found her out in exactly one cycle anyway). Your goal is to infiltrate return or prevent return altogether. This doesn't help you; this doesn't help us. All this does is turn our game into a shitty one while you are still guaranteed to lose. Finola : No matter how will You look at this - it is simply bad Mushplay Both - cheap and not allowing Mush to win
Jin Su : Hey, I could have easily set fire to the place /and/ took the extinguishers. We were planning on converting someone, and even got halfway there. Janice just bailed on the plan and got herself exposed, and ruined the plan.
Ian : I have Firefighter skill unlocked. That skill allows one to put out fires without extinguishers. If I'm not playing Ian, I always hide or safekeep an extinguisher or BP
Jin Su : Yeah. I don't appreciate being called crap straight from the get go, though. I had a plan, I was going to stick to it, and then my partner messes it up. I admit hopping in the pasiphae is cheap, but I could have done a lot worse than this.
Ian : "Doing a lot worse" is supposed to be your job, you know. If you're trying to say we're supposed to be thankful for your mercy of "just" taking the pasiphae, you're missing the point of both pasiphae hijacking and the game
Jin Su : Fine. let's get this over so we don't waste any more gold days then, eh?

My question first is, what parts of this is against SDF rules? I assume the confessing and XP farming is against the rules but I'm not sure if landing the ship into almost certain death is a form of playing against the team as well.

In addition, since most of the crew already reported him for confessing, we can no longer report him again for becoming inactive in the days following. (SDF only gets the first message sent from each person, about each other person). What should I do in such a situation where I need to report someone twice for two different things, or updating the same report?
On august 13, 2015
npfan
NERONIn addition, since most of the crew already reported him for confessing, we can no longer report him again for becoming inactive in the days following. (SDF only gets the first message sent from each person, about each other person). What should I do in such a situation where I need to report someone twice for two different things, or updating the same report?

Let me answer this first, since this is easier to answer. When you report someone, the judges will look at everything the reported person did (and any relevant actions by other players). If the judges find that the person reported broke more rules than was reported, the judges will rule for all rules broken, not just the ones reported. Having said that, if you feel you need to update a report, one idea to try is to ask someone who hasn't reported the reported person yet to report any new information.

To go back to your first question, here's a list of rules possibly broken based on what you posted:

  • Mush admitting not causing the most damage to the humans
  • (Attempted) Pathetic suicide
  • Anti-mush play
  • XP farming
  • Hurting the human team as a human
On august 31, 2015
Multigrain

Instead of playing it out the mush rampaged (Set fires and dismantled fire extinguishers) and essentially threw a tantrum about how its pointless to play with only one mush at the start.
On august 31, 2015
[6826491]

It's not forbidden. It may be frowned upon by some players, but the tactic itself is valid. The tantrum isn't so great, but that is a separate issue (an attitude problem, really.)

On september 8, 2015
[8337275]

Situation: We have a player on our current ship who wanders around, we believe following the tooltips, but doesn't communicate in any of the chats and generally isn't helpful. He's not really hurting the ship, but he's not really helping it either.

Question: What are our legal actions regarding this player? We have already attempted communication through PM's with no response.
On september 8, 2015
Kyubey
DrWinner

Situation: We have a player on our current ship who wanders around, we believe following the tooltips, but doesn't communicate in any of the chats and generally isn't helpful. He's not really hurting the ship, but he's not really helping it either.

Question: What are our legal actions regarding this player? We have already attempted communication through PM's with no response.

No reason to report him in my opinion.

If you think, there is a good chance he was converted (staying in rooms like bays for long) - you can kill him.
If you think, there is a good chance he is alpha-mush who just play as such new player (often visits BD, has much more ap then he's using, passing rooms like Raluca room/medlab) - you can kill him too.

If you are sure, that he's human and don't do anything wrong (holding stuff like apron, finishing wrong projects, kicking people from beds), it's probably better to leave him alone.
On september 8, 2015
[6384940]
DrWinnerWe have already attempted communication through PM's with no response.

DarkTheRaven

In that case you've exhausted all your methods of communication and they're not listening. From what I remember of previous answers to similar situations you retain the right to kill them once you have tried to communicate and given them adequate time to answer if they are unresponsive, especially if you suspect mushrooms have a hand

[8244601]

I have a few questions:

- If we cure a mush, and now s/he's an human, can s/he reveal who are the mushs left?

- Can mushs play safely (almost like humans) in order not to allow humans come back to Sol?

- May someone become dirty after hugging the cat?
On september 13, 2015
DarkTheRaven

Yes a cured mush is expected to give up his teamates as they're now human

Yes, infecting sol quietly is a valid tactic

No, hugging the cat can injure but not make you dirty

Also this thread is used to ask rule related questions such as your first/second, your third should be put in the Q&A thread
On september 13, 2015
NERON

Mush may reveal everything when cured or reveal nothing at all. If they choose to reveal things, they may not choose to reveal the only parts of the picture, nor can they lie

Mush may play safe and act completely human with the intent to infiltrate Sol, but only if this tactic has reasonable chance of succeeding given the circumstances
On september 13, 2015
DarkTheRaven

Last i heard since you're now human you can't hide info from your team, because you'd be playing against your team
On september 13, 2015
NERON

Then you need to do some more reading

Judges were very clear in some previous posts that you're allowed to reveal nothing at all to the humans when cured. The only thing against the rules in that situation is if you tell lies or partial truths regarding the remaining mush. Also, if a much chooses to do this, humans may legally threaten to kill and follow through with the threat
On september 13, 2015

On september 13, 2015
NERON

Not a good habit to post ship info in the forums, your mush might figure out what you're planning, we gotta be super sneaky as humans tooOn a related note, for my own future reference, what happens if one discovers a mush from information found outside of the game (In the forums or IRC for example)?

Would it be against the rules to act on this information? Technically you have no recorded proof of mushood since only things in the game are saved for judging purposes

Would it be against the rules not to act on this information? You're letting a known mush run around, after all

What would be the safest course of action?
On september 13, 2015
Aceb

I think that you could get sanctioned if judges won't be able to find you reasons to kill one, assuming that you have been reported. (Random killing, even if you hit mush, is still a random kill and can get sanctioned from what I remember).

Safest action would be to find enough clues/proofs to justify bloodshed.
Some people can separate "character knowledge" from player knowledge, but even with that ability, you still stare at other player as potential dead body in his future, "because you know and suspect".
On september 13, 2015
npfan
NERON

Would it be against the rules not to act on this information? You're letting a known mush run around, after all

What would be the safest course of action?

That depends what it means to have a Mush 'known'. If a player says something that just so happens to be similar to your ship, then that's invalid because you don't for sure if something is mere coincidence or not. On the other hand, if someone makes it blatantly obvious (e.g. posts a screenshot with unique information), then if you choose to act on that information, make sure that information is posted somewhere in the ship.

"El ex-mush, ahora humano, est obligado a delatar a su compaero.
Las normas del juego dicen que no debes actuar contra tu propio bando, y si eres humano, eres humano."

I translate: "The cured-mush, now human, MUST reveal their fellows.
Game rules say you don't have to act against your own team, and if you're an human, then you have to play like an human."

Is it possible??

Yes. You can be reported always. Refusing to take a shower is not a thing you will be sanctioned for. You don't must be afraid.

On september 16, 2015
Peanutz
Mais pourquoi est-il aussi mchant ?

You cannot force people to do a mush test (either a food test or any other kind of test). You can suggest it, but if they refuse, you cannot kill them just for that.

Spending time in a room that wasn't protected isn't enough to kill someone either.
On september 16, 2015
Aceb
KiruboWe killed two mush on our ship but Eleesha printed the list to get the first one. Chun thinks that there might be an anonymush and has asked everyone on the ship to take a food test. Is this allowed?

She might ask to anyone to do one, but Chun Player Can't Force Anyone. Everyone can refuse and be fine with that.

She's also stated that we should kill 2 of the crew if they refuse, because "they spent a long period of time in an insecure area". The insecure areas were the medlab and lab, which didn't have cameras. Is this enough reason to kill them if they refuse to take the test?

It's force test, which is reportable. Spending a long period of time in an insecure area might be some clue but not force testing. Force test is a reportable thing and not within spirit of the game.

On september 21, 2015
[8794477]

So surprisingly I managed to squeeze some valid info out of the forum search (yay!) re: converting a human and killing them. The ruling by (Peanutz I think it was) was that is was OK with the caveat that you had to immediately kill them.


My question is a slight variation - can you set up extreme suspicion on a human who is acting very mush-like, and then convert him, take anonymush, and let the human team burn their AP to kill them? It's very close to the original ruling, but since there were strict rules laid out, and this is slightly different, is this OK?

Related to that: Is it OK to do the same thing after converting them if you establish that this is your plan from the outset before conversion? I.e. Human crewmember X is behaving very mush like, and he's (insert big human no-no here like getting dirty in bravo dorm or we slime-trapped him) can we convert them and then immediately denounce them and try to get the human team to spend the bulk of their AP killing them?
On september 21, 2015
npfan
ZombieLawnGnomeMy question is a slight variation - can you set up extreme suspicion on a human who is acting very mush-like, and then convert him, take anonymush, and let the human team burn their AP to kill them? It's very close to the original ruling, but since there were strict rules laid out, and this is slightly different, is this OK?

You could do that, although I wonder why you wouldn't just grow the Mush team if you can do that.

ZombieLawnGnomeRelated to that: Is it OK to do the same thing after converting them if you establish that this is your plan from the outset before conversion? I.e. Human crewmember X is behaving very mush like, and he's (insert big human no-no here like getting dirty in bravo dorm or we slime-trapped him) can we convert them and then immediately denounce them and try to get the human team to spend the bulk of their AP killing them?

I'm not sure how you can immediately denounce a new Mush if the new Mush hasn't done anything obvious. The humans need some reasonable justification to kill someone as Mush. If you simply shout so-and-so is dirty and must be Mush, the humans may not necessarily go along with you.
On september 21, 2015
[8794477]

First, thank you for your professional consideration Npfan. You and I have had some... friction in the past that I will not dredge up other than to say I applaud your ability to answer be impartially and honestly despite earlier tension.

As to your points:

npfanYou could do that, although I wonder why you wouldn't just grow the Mush team if you can do that.

As with so much of mush play, it's situational. You can use it to 'prove' that all the alphas are dead ('It says so right there on the bar, doesn't it?') You could use several strategies to bring this about other than direct spiking, especially one that would leave the humans doubting a beta was created.

Maybe you don't have confidence in this person's ability/willingness to play well when converted. Maybe this person wouldn't make a particularly strong addition to your strategy on his/her own merits, but as a patsy, provides real value.

npfanI'm not sure how you can immediately denounce a new Mush if the new Mush hasn't done anything obvious. The humans need some reasonable justification to kill someone as Mush. If you simply shout so-and-so is dirty and must be Mush, the humans may not necessarily go along with you.

This would be for 'that guy' who you know as a mush is human, but is playing so badly/anti-socially (not necessarily in a sanctionable way) that he/she would likely have been killed soon on those merits alone, and now makes an excellent stalking horse.

Both of the variations have the effect of misleading the crew that the alphas were dead and it's safe to go back to Sol/head towards Eden.

This wouldn't necessarily beat the best players in full-blown paranoia mode, but then there never was a 'silver bullet' mush strategy that will win against the likes of Peanutz and the rest of the 'Mod Squad.'
On september 21, 2015
npfan

Right, I understand the benefits of those strategies. I'm just saying that in general, the Mush shouldn't have to push the humans to kill a patsy. Just convert the player, and let that player help the Mush team. Maybe the Mush team can tell the beta that the humans plan to kill him soon, so rampage. Now, if you're afraid the guy's a griefer or might hurt the Mush team, you can try to push the humans to kill him. Win-win for everyone except the griefer.

The main scenario the SDF wants to avoid is one Mush trying to throw another Mush under the bus in a way that hurts the Mush team. For example, two alphas make a beta. One alpha argues with the beta. The three of them could work together to help the Mush win, but instead the alpha denounces the beta for personal gain. With the added factor of killing the beta immediately after conversion, one could argue it would be just as if a bad human was killed with the added benefit it looks like an alpha Mush was killed, and if it's a Mush that did the killing, the Mush might gain some trust from the humans.

npfan

You will get logs about receiving morale, but in reality, you get nothing. That's just one of the risks of transfer.
On september 24, 2015
[6826491]
ToutiorixHi,
I was a mush and transfered to a human with 0 morale, on cycle change i died for fatal depression, its a bug?

It's not a bug. Mush have no way to gain or lose morale, by any means. Even though they may see the morale messages, their morale value can't change. If you transfer into someone with zero morale, you're guaranteed to be dead the following cycle. If you Transfer into them while they have one or more morale, then your value will read as 14 (16 if Gold.)
On september 24, 2015
sperbi

Why is that not a bug? Mushes can't do anything to prevent their death then.
This is a bug or I declare myself totally insane..
On september 24, 2015
[6826491]

Mush can never gain or lose morale. That mechanic is intended, and as npfan stated, it is a risk one faces when using Transfer. So, why would anyone expect Mush to suddenly be able to gain morale after a Transfer?
On september 24, 2015
[1820396]
sperbiWhy is that not a bug? Mushes can't do anything to prevent their death then.

Not entirely true. They may count morale of the potential targets of theirs and chose one, which isn't on 0. Granted, it's not easy, but who said everything has to be easy?
On september 24, 2015
sperbi
SpazticusMush can never gain or lose morale. That mechanic is intended, and as npfan stated, it is a risk one faces when using Transfer. So, why would anyone expect Mush to suddenly be able to gain morale after a Transfer?

Because normally they always get full morale the cycle after a transfer.
Because they don't change their morale, because they are not supposed to die of morale loss?
Mushes are creatures which don't die of demoralization, because they are NOT humans.
It makes absolutely no snese for a mush to die of demoralization therefore.
On september 24, 2015

On september 24, 2015
Flash

Technically it's more of an oversight than a bug and as to why it's still in the game I guess it comes down to whether the devs see a compelling reason to spend their valuable time on fixing it

On september 24, 2015
[6826491]

The logical conclusion is that the check for a depression death event happens before the Mush would be at "full" morale. It's probably among the very first events that gets checked for each player at every cycle change. We've never been able to establish exactly what order events happen, or which are intended to take precedence.

It can and does happen to kill Mush on occasion, and the devs have never acknowledged it as a bug.

Speculate on the why and how of it all you like, but please, not in this thread.
On september 24, 2015
Peanutz
Mais pourquoi est-il aussi mchant ?

Hmm... Actually, the Mush can never lose morale, but they can gain some by the usual ways, except for food or pills. Their morale is at maximum as soon as they become Mush, but after a transfer, they keep their new body's morale and it will remain the same unless they sleep in the same room as a shrink, cuddle the cat, do the thing...
On september 24, 2015
TeufelsAdvokat

On september 25, 2015
kreton

On september 25, 2015
Peanutz
Mais pourquoi est-il aussi mchant ?

First of all, let's please stop derailing the thread. This doesn't concern the SDF or reports.

Second of all, read my message just above. You are able to increase your morale if you are mush, using all the possible methods (speeches, doing the thing, chitchatting with Andie, cuddling the cat...) except for food and pills.

The only thing that can't happen to a mush is their morale decreasing.

On december 10, 2015
BadBlanket

It's difficult to realize what happened in the background. What kind of evidence they picked up, whether valid or not, and who they were talking to. It's surprising how easy it is to convince people that someone is suspicious as a mush. I've done it many times which have led to humans killing humans.

If you weren't dirty and she said you were then there's something not adding up, though. Also simply walking into the shower dorm isn't necessarily reason to immediately kill someone. You should try to state when you're dirty immediately after you get dirty to avoid people screaming at you as active ships will watch the shower dorm close.

In the future, if you think there was foul play, you should report it. If Janice would have turned out to be mush then she would've been cleared but she wasn't. Without the report, though, there isn't much anyone can do about it. We can see their name after the fact but the evidence is all lost as we can't bring up anything regarding the ship or the actions/dialogue that took place.

Holding weapons, armor, hacker kit, etc prior to mush selection is a violation of neutral play (even for Chun). Just put them on the floor, you're free to tell Chun where they are and she can handle them after mush selection.
On december 17, 2015
Cadenza
Dvoreur des mondes
