On december 17, 2015
BadBlanket
JouishyHow is this not neutral? I'd do the same if I was mush or human.

Because if you end up human after selection and have that gear then you hand them straight to Chun. If you're Mush after selection then you may hide them or use them to kill someone. If they're on the floor, everyone has a chance to do something with them after selection. You may say "If I'm Mush I will drop them" but not everyone (in fact barely anyone) has that frame of mind. Also hoarding weapons is sometimes a sign that that person might be a griefer. The knife is the most dangerous weapon (barring wrestler) in the game and the armor makes it that much more difficult for someone to be killed so I wouldn't necessarily call them unimportant, they're just important in another sense.
On december 17, 2015
[6826491]

Your crew is correct, and Badblanket is correct. Items may be moved, but may not not kept in your inventory prior to selection. Let's say it's not the weapons, but the apron. If Chun is holding that apron before selection, and she then goes inactive for a day, the early game research is significantly hindered by that act. This is part of the reason that not even Chun is exempt from the Neutral Play rules. We enforce the rule in order to give neither team an unfair advantage at the moment of selection.

Any time you're forced to kill a player as a last resort to get them to drop critical items (and it happens more often than you'd think) it costs the crew AP, morale, and a potentially active player. If people aren't holding items prior to selection, the chance of such "murders of necessity" drops significantly.
On december 17, 2015
Kenik

To compound this: On a roleplay front, the mush don't know they're mush, and the humans don't know their are mush aboard UNTIL mush selection. Holding onto those items before then would be a bother that isn't worth the energy when there's no threat aboard.
Just wanted this tidbit a bit more available.
On december 17, 2015
NERON

I don't think those are the best examples for this situation, guys

JouishyHow is this not neutral? I'd do the same if I was mush or human.

If you give the stuff to Chun whether you are mush or not (as you intend), the mush team will have a disadvantage and humans will have an unfair advantage. In other words, you're taking steps to play for the human team before the mush even exist to do anything about it.


BadBlanketHolding weapons, armor, hacker kit, etc prior to mush selection is a violation of neutral play (even for Chun) Not just that, holding anything that you picked up off the floor is a violation of neutral play. The only stuff you're allowed to hold is your communication items, skill-generated items and vending machine goods

On december 17, 2015
BadBlanket
DraconicEpicI have a question and I'm not sure if it is answered or not (I haven't seen an answer). Is it a viable tactic for the Mush to simply get four Mush then idle in Icarus Bay till the ship eventually falls apart. To me it seem something reportable since it completely breaks the spirit of the game and definitely isn't fair play.

Definitely not against the rules. It's a pretty looked down on tactic, though, just like taking off with extinguishers and pyro. There is a bit of skill and luck involved in being able to turn two others who would be online fast enough for the group to fill up in IB, though. Chances are, 4 mush could decimate the crew quicker than the hunters would be able to, though. If a mush uses this tactic, consider it a fun little challenge to figure out a way to kill them while keeping the ship afloat because, if they wanted to, they could just leave IB and murder spree 80% of the ship. Two people, alone, (with the right skills) can decimate a ship.

Your crew is correct, and Badblanket is correct. Items may be moved, but may not not kept in your inventory prior to selection. Let's say it's not the weapons, but the apron. If Chun is holding that apron before selection, and she then goes inactive for a day, the early game research is significantly hindered by that act. This is part of the reason that not even Chun is exempt from the Neutral Play rules. We enforce the rule in order to give neither team an unfair advantage at the moment of selection.

Any time you're forced to kill a player as a last resort to get them to drop critical items (and it happens more often than you'd think) it costs the crew AP, morale, and a potentially active player. If people aren't holding items prior to selection, the chance of such "murders of necessity" drops significantly.

Well, if I am mush, I can drop the item, tell Chun in private where it is, tell my co-mush where it is too, or hide it in a room and telling them both. Chun can't hold onto everything, so hiding is often a good solution. Telling her I hid the item somewhere, there are many chances she won't go search for it to hide it back (still possible, but the most of the time). Then, no team is disadvantaged. Also, if my co-mush want to go rampage, the weapons will be in our hands.

On december 18, 2015
BadBlanket
NERONIn these instances, whichever team you are assigned to gets the unfair advantage.

^^^ Yes.

Installing cameras is allowed because, without the cameras, the humans would be at an EXTREME disadvantage. Humans need a place to camp out safely. Projects are always gain one, lose two. So where there's benefit there is also loss. As for research, normally the Mycoscan would be against the rules but this episode makes it so that people start with random spores. The early mycoscan helps to balance that (and I have yet to be on a ship that actually does mycoscan prior to selection, it's usually lenses).

[8281990]

Part of the benefit the neutral play rules: lessening the imbalance based on when you join the ship. Early joiners would get first pick of the weapons/tools to hold, while the last person to join has the advantage of being immediately active.

On december 19, 2015
NERON

This is just the way the rules are. Arguing with us on the logic won't change a thing. It's not as if us forum goers have the power to change the SDF rules

On december 19, 2015
[6826491]

The rules were established during beta, over two years ago. Short of having a time machine to go back and forcibly change our minds, the rules aren't likely to change in this timeline. Further, since the creator of Mush has left MT, it is even more unlikely that we will have any new circumstances to force a change in the rules.

This was long debated in the SDF, and the Neutral Play rules were set up to be fair to everyone. If no critical items are kept in the inventory of any player, then everyone has an equal chance to pick them up at the moment of Mush selection, regardless of whether they were first or last to wake up. This is why we ruled that they may be moved, but not kept. It is not justifiable to claim that you're "holding it for Chun", "keeping it safe", or "keeping it for yourself"; the rule forbids keeping those items.

Holding critical items was ruled to be effectively the same as hiding them, when items could be hidden prior to selection. While items can't be hidden prior to selection any longer, when people hold items in order to deny them to others...they are doing it in order to have an advantage. We are maintaining the rule to prevent that advantage from being gained. Chun is subject to this rule as well, so being Chun does not grant an exception, either.

Ultimately, there is no point in trying to get us to change the rule, regardless of whether you agree with it. The rule exists with good reason, and will continue to exist to provide as fair a start as possible for each player, regardless of their team.
On december 19, 2015
Cadenza
Dvoreur des mondes

Well, I'm surprised to learn all this now, considering the number of ships I've done on that server and that I always do this when I have the chance to. Before, I was always hiding the grenade without taking it (so I hid it in the room it was at the beggining) and depending if I end up mush or human, I either tell my co-mush where it was, or I tell Chun. I never heard before yesterday that all this was forbidden (I know that now, it is not forbidden to hide thing prior to mush selection : it is impossible).

The only neutral play I've heard of was concerning the researches : no anti-mush research before mush designation. Now, that is taken care of by the fact the sample isn't in the ship at that point, so researches are impossible.
On december 19, 2015
[6826491]

On december 22, 2015
Cadenza
Dvoreur des mondes

What is "Spreadsheets"?
The astropad, for instance? Are there others?
On december 22, 2015
NERON

There are spreadsheets that exist for copy/pasting room logs during the mush phase and for keeping track of crew health in the late game. Of course, people could always make more for other utilities. Some versions are available on the forums for public use. I've made my own variations.

These are typically google docs, so you can share the same spreadsheet with your crew if you wish. That's what the spreadsheet clause is referring to
On december 23, 2015

On january 11, 2016
[2829818]

Mage Books and neutral play: For several characters an additional skill can come in very handy, like Bronze Eleesha or Bronze Chun p.e.

Is it considered a violation of the neutral play rules reading mage books pre-mush? Since Chun always stays human it seems like a disadvantage for the mush if she does.
On january 11, 2016
[6826491]

The initial mage book does not spawn until the moment the ship fills up. No mage books can be gained from Xyloph until after Mush selection, and a Comms officer is chosen.
On january 11, 2016
spacekadt
AvengingAngel

Mage Books and neutral play: For several characters an additional skill can come in very handy, like Bronze Eleesha or Bronze Chun p.e.

Is it considered a violation of the neutral play rules reading mage books pre-mush? Since Chun always stays human it seems like a disadvantage for the mush if she does.

To expand slightly on Spaz's answer, neutral play applies to all characters - even Chun. If we allowed Chun to do things like hoard weapons before selection (to use a random possible example), it's still an unfair advantage for the human team. The goal is to have mush and humans have an *equal* chance at the moment the ship fills. Once that happens, it's a glorious free for all in seeing who's online and who can sneakily get to what first.
On january 11, 2016
Secondary

I just returned to the game after a long break, and started as Stephen, before ship actualy started I held the blaster to give it to chun when she spawned or someone else trustworthy afterwards, I had forgotten about the SDF rules of neutral play and did not realise there would be something like that before it was too late. Am I in trouble for this?
On january 11, 2016
Aceb

If someone did report you for breaking neutral play, you will get a SDF point. Not much so you don't have to worry. Eventually you will be able to contact mods and talk about this if you get information about a punishment.

[1820396]

On january 14, 2016
[6826491]

The game has to be played out to its logical conclusion, because surrender is strictly forbidden - as is "co-operating" with the Mush on random ships. Any human in that instance is still required to resist, even if they are guaranteed to fail. It would be playing against their team to work with the Mush, and the Mush aren't allowed to make such an offer to the last human...to entice someone to play against their team would spoil the game. Similarly, being voluntarily converted would spoil the game.

Even as Ian, a human player can still fight back, without committing suicide. A rampage could do the trick, even if it fails, because the Mush team might opt to kill rather than wait to be killed. As long as the attempt to further the team's goals is made in earnest, it can hardly be called a suicide.

On january 19, 2016
Kenik

If you suspect they're mush, and they use a common(obvious) mush obfuscation technique. Then you are welcome to consider that incriminating(and therefor death worthy) evidence.

However if you are sure they're human then killing them is criminal.
On january 19, 2016
Cross

Keyword = solely

Absolutely no other reasons to suspect they're mush, and you certainly can't be sure they're human. Hypothetically, let's say mush selection happened an hour ago, not much activity going on, not much communication yet across the whole ship, and a character confides in Andie with nothing but examine actions and walks away about their business. Is that enough of a reason to justify a kill?

A human might want to do this because they want the morale but want to keep their privacy, or scoff at the skill because it's akin to a voluntary mushtest. Or should a human be obliged to transparency in their actions should they choose to confide?

Thanks for your time and response.

spacekadt
npfanTrying to undermine investigation as a human in general can be seen as playing against their team. However, there are legitimate reasons a human may press Examine a lot.

Keep in mind that while this can be true, it can also be very, very false.

As mentioned later, Andie wasn't confirmed human and could have used human actions for mushy purposes. There's also the aspect of human play that wants to keep it away from cheap tactics to prove humanity. I know a number of people that go to great lengths to never double eat in front of people or under a camera or do anything else that might prove their humanity.

Using Examine 16 times before confiding in Andie could be seen as sketchy, sure, but it's also a way to avoid what is essentially a mush test. (But unless you're an extremely trusted human, know that as a human, it's more likely to get you killed when you do it. And usually rightfully so.)

On january 19, 2016
NERON

There's also the aspect of human play that wants to keep it away from cheap tactics to prove humanity. I know a number of people that go to great lengths to never double eat in front of people or under a camera or do anything else that might prove their humanity.

Using Examine 16 times before confiding in Andie could be seen as sketchy, sure, but it's also a way to avoid what is essentially a mush test.Doing that sounds almost like intentionally breaking the game

This isn't the same as food testing. The mush's inability to eat much is the result of devs limiting the amount of damage mush can do by eating all the rations, not because they want to give humans a way to confirm themselves. They had to program food this way because all the other systems they came up with were equally or more unbalanced

If the devs thought Confidant was unbalanced, they could have simply not made it the way it is. There's no reason for Confidant to reveal parts of player action logs unless this interaction with the hunt was the dev's intention
On january 19, 2016
sperbi

The big advantage of confidant is that a player is not forced to reveal log, but can decide to confide or not.
If there are players who would spam examine just to hide eventually a food testing (theoretically it would also not be proven, you would have to check afterwards whether eating of both things happened really in same or following cycles), then they make themselves voluntarily suspicious, which may mislead the mush hunt and even if they don't get killed because mush hunters are careful, it may lead to the situation that mush hunters overlook the real mushes.
That being said, I am no friend of easy confirmations as well. But instead of just spamming examine and making himself voluntarily suspicious therefore (which probably can be seen in some way as playing against their team), the player can in most cases decide to just confide only after doing some other helpful things and therefore hiding possible confirmations unless he needs really urgently and immediately a morale boost. Or just avoid to double eat at all.
On january 22, 2016
NERON

SpazticusYou are explicitly forbidden from making a suboptimal skill choice, IF that choice is intended to make the game "more challenging". That reasoning is exactly why it is explicitly forbidden to make that skill choice. "Making the game more challenging" is NOT an acceptable reason to choose (or not choose) a skill.

Similar examples of this logic would be Chun not taking MOH, because she "wants the game to be more challenging", or Janice not taking Shrink, for the same reason. We have sanctioned players for behavior like this, because it amounts to playing against the team.Source : http://twd.io/e/7F310w/98

What happens if instead of making the game more challenging, the player picks IT over shrink "because I can" and then refuses to acknowledge all further (numerous) inquiries on the matter? The player possesses advanced knowledge of the game as seen in posts so it's impossible they would skip shrink because they don't know any better
On january 22, 2016
Cross

Well, it must be acceptable to not take MOH or Shrink under some circumstances, otherwise why would bronze players even be allowed to level up Chun or Janice? Lethargy I could see an easy argument for, but any of Chun's or Janice's other skills?
On january 22, 2016
TeufelsAdvokat
NERON

Source : http://twd.io/e/7F310w/98

What happens if instead of making the game more challenging, the player picks IT over shrink "because I can" and then refuses to acknowledge all further (numerous) inquiries on the matter? The player possesses advanced knowledge of the game as seen in posts so it's impossible they would skip shrink because they don't know any better

"Because I can" is no good reason to skip a vital skill like Shrink and should be reportable as it makes the game harder.

CrossWell, it must be acceptable to not take MOH or Shrink under some circumstances, otherwise why would bronze players even be allowed to level up Chun or Janice? Lethargy I could see an easy argument for, but any of Chun's or Janice's other skills?

I can see a situation of a bronze Janice taking Diplomat if there are plenty of other morale sources. For the most part though, it's not so much whether you have to by the rules choose certain skills, it's more the reasoning behind choosing skills.
On january 22, 2016
[8550239]
TeufelsAdvokat"Because I can" is no good reason to skip a vital skill like Shrink and should be reportable as it makes the game harder.

I fully disagree with this being reportable, the games is designed so that you can pick any skill you wish and players should not be penalised for their choice of skill as it is their choice. though you can free feel to be upset that someone didn't take an important skill and be suspicious of them.
On january 22, 2016
[6826491]
NGJonI fully disagree with this being reportable, the games is designed so that you can pick any skill you wish and players should not be penalised for their choice of skill as it is their choice. though you can free feel to be upset that someone didn't take an important skill and be suspicious of them.

Just because one can do something, does not mean that they should.

It's reportable, because the game forbids playing against your team. "Because I can" is not an acceptable reason to choose a suboptimal skill. It's not the choice, but the attitude and reasoning behind that choice that is sanctionable, in this case. Or, to put it another way, the player's willingness to make the game harder to win, at the expense of the rest of their team.

I have personally sanctioned players who have taken a suboptimal skill choice because, and I quote just one example, they "wanted to make the game more challenging." If they want to make the game more challenging, there are casting options they can play with, and that others consent to before they jump. A relatively new NOF-only Janice can still contribute to a ship. Maybe they're just trying out the skill for the first time, and don't know that some of the early skills are optimal for Bronze players. An experienced Janice player that is NOF-only, because they "wanted to make the game more challenging" has made that skill choice, with the intention of hurting their team's chances to win.

See how the difference in attitude brings forth our retribution?

A newbie may not know better, and may indeed think that higher level skills are inherently better - at least until someone experienced counters that line of thinking. Why they chose that skill matters.

Would we sanction a first time Roland player just for being Sprinter-only? Of course not, especially if that's the only thing for which they are being accused. A player who has survived a few dozen ships, and clearly knows better won't get the same leeway if they were to do the same.
On january 22, 2016
PanterD2S

....and if theres no reason given?
On january 22, 2016
Peanutz
Mais pourquoi est-il aussi mchant ?

I think there are several degrees of seriousness :

- A beginner who picks a skill because they don't realize that it is "inferior". I recently had a newbie Chun who picked Nurse because she thought it was better for the crew, since it benefited everyone while MOH only benefited her. That is not reportable.

- A player who picks a skill because they think that it is not inferior and /or is useful. Their crew members may or may not agree with the choice, but remember that there is a different between a bad player, someone who makes "bad" choices, and a griefer. I put "bad" between quotation marks because it is subjective. Very often, Jin Su is called a griefer if he picks Leader instead of Pilot, and on other ships he's considered a griefer if he picks Pilot, just because people have automatisms and preconceived ideas about "optimal" skills, instead of basing themselves on the situation on each different ship. Another example is Andie, with some players who think that they should always pick Polyvalent (the problem is that players should wait before choosing their skills, in order to choose the right skill for a particular ship ; but that is another problem, not discussed here). In my opinion, that is not reportable either if the chosen skill is useful for the crew and the absence of the rejected skill doesn't harm the ship.

- Slightly more serious, someone who picks a skill that, without being vital, would be more useful than the one they chose. That's the case we're discussing here. IT Expert is not useless, far from it, but Shrink is usually more important. You can, however, consider that choosing IT Expert is not a bad idea. There are several possible justifications : that ship has other morale sources (Confidant, Leader...), you prefer the advantages offered by IT Expert, you consider that a ship can survive easily without a shrink (after all, a shrink can be inactive or mush, or she can be killed, and it doesn't mean that the crew is doomed). If the player gives reasonable justifications and genuinely thinks that they choice is good for the crew, it is not reportable. Again, you may or may not agree with those justifications, but that doesn't mean that this player is a griefer (but if you have doubts, report and let the judges decide).

- Same situation, but without a single justification, or just "I chose it because I can, look, it's allowed". That is reportable.

- Again, same situation but "I chose it because I don't want to make the game too easy". As Spaz explained, the player is aware that they are making things difficult for their side, and that's reportable.

- Finally, those who pick a skill explicitly to harm the ship, and they're usually not going to stop there. Those are griefers who of course should be reported.

Let me stress one last thing : in most cases (except the last one, and maybe the one before), killing that player will not make the situation better. In fact, it can make it worse (waste of AP, loss of morale, loss of an active player) and can, in some situations, be reported too.
On january 22, 2016
Cross

Very well written post and appreciated, but it leads me to one question since you seem to indicate the justification for the skill choice is key in regards to sanctions. The question would be then, is a human player obligated to justify their choices to their crew, or are they able to justify themselves after a report is being investigated (therefore after the ship has ended)?
On january 22, 2016
Aceb
CrossVery well written post and appreciated, but it leads me to one question since you seem to indicate the justification for the skill choice is key in regards to sanctions. The question would be then, is a human player obligated to justify their choices to their crew, or are they able to justify themselves after a report is being investigated (therefore after the ship has ended)?

Usually reporting person is not quiet about it, which leds usually to the people being reported to post their explanation like:

Andie: Janice reported for not taking shrink! omgone1!one!1eon!1
<reports is made>
Janice: I did pick IT Expert and Diplomat, because I believe, we have enough morale givers and I can focus on expos/nexus.

Other way it is possible for this example, that Janice is a mush who want to use IT Expert to get rid useful project and Diplomat for ceasefire for her comrades.

If someone is mostly silent and no explanation is given, probably details decide here.

Whoever, if the report is silent and the player has no idea He/She was reported, logs are reviewed anyway, where again, details decide.

Also, remember that you can open private channel with yourself only and post your explanation in case you are afraid but your point is valid enough and it is not against your crew.
On january 22, 2016
npfan
CrossVery well written post and appreciated, but it leads me to one question since you seem to indicate the justification for the skill choice is key in regards to sanctions. The question would be then, is a human player obligated to justify their choices to their crew, or are they able to justify themselves after a report is being investigated (therefore after the ship has ended)?

A written justification is not mandatory, but can be useful. Someone who may without explanation have picked a skillset the crew disagrees with but is otherwise as helpful as can be may be seen as someone who chose skill(s) without malice, and could be cleared of wrongdoing. However, someone who is clearly experienced and doesn't try to explain choosing a skillset that people with experience would know is not most useful to their team could be sanctioned. Even if the worst case scenario happens where someone who acted without malice gets sanctioned, they can appeal to the mods and try to justify to them. If the mods see that the player had some reasonable explanation that the judges perhaps did not consider, the sanction will be removed.

On january 23, 2016
Cross

I am not SDF, just a player, so my opinion may rightly be judged as worthless, but I'll give it to you anyways. Frieda in this example is a risk-taker, and there is a reward in this case: Progress. She may not have the greatest attitude, particularly that part of pointing out it's a random ship. She may be acting against consensus, which if there's anything that's could get her in trouble it might be that one. I could see the crew deciding to eliminate the liability as much more justified than a sanction though, and if she were on my ship I wouldn't even consider reporting her. I'm pretty sure there's nothing in the rules that requires you to take every precaution against possible mush actions. On the contrary, the more both teams are given opportunities to slip up makes for a more interesting and exciting game. If everybody had to take every precaution, it'd be a chess game where gambits don't exist and every move is clear and predetermined.

npfan

CrossI am not SDF, just a player, so my opinion may rightly be judged as worthless, but I'll give it to you anyways. Frieda in this example is a risk-taker, and there is a reward in this case: Progress. She may not have the greatest attitude, particularly that part of pointing out it's a random ship. She may be acting against consensus, which if there's anything that's could get her in trouble it might be that one. I could see the crew deciding to eliminate the liability as much more justified than a sanction though, and if she were on my ship I wouldn't even consider reporting her. I'm pretty sure there's nothing in the rules that requires you to take every precaution against possible mush actions. On the contrary, the more both teams are given opportunities to slip up makes for a more interesting and exciting game. If everybody had to take every precaution, it'd be a chess game where gambits don't exist and every move is clear and predetermined.

There's taking risk (especially necessary risk), and there's being so reckless that you put the whole crew in danger of losing. The former is fine, the latter is considered playing against the team. I don't know where this case falls because I don't know all the details, but anyone that's that reckless in general would likely get killed and/or sanctioned.

On january 23, 2016
[6826491]

A ship that loses the Icarus on its first planet will likely not have any shot at Eden, and its long term survival chances are greatly reduced. Even if the planet itself is safe enough to have a 0% chance of a solo expo resulting in death, the Mush might deem it worth the risk to deprive the ship of the Icarus early on. That kind of early loss may hinder the human team's morale.

Specific details aside, I agree with npfan here: Just because one player determines that a solo expo is worth the risk, does not give that player the freedom to act on that conclusion without any consequences. If the crew consents, that's different - and arguably better. Desperation may force immediate action to take place, even with the risk involved. Therein lies the major difference. A crew making that decision and taking that risk, is better than one person deciding it on their own, and proceeding on their own regardless of the consequences.
On january 23, 2016
TeufelsAdvokat

Add the player to the dependencies too. She's possibly Gold(+2 HP) and/or has Survivalist(-1 dmg from accidents and stuff). Especially if the planet has a lot of Fatigue it may have been even better for her to solo it.

I've seen some bits of chat from this ship. Unpleasant, I agree. That would look way more powerful and would show way better example than appealing to high court in any uncomfortable situation. Just like it would in real life, I believe.
To conclude that, I assure you - I've seen similar and even worse situations bounded with DTT The worst thing is, they happen in times of low morale, so refusing means harming the gameplay for roleplaying sake. Wiggling out of these is quite a good training for one's diplomatic skill and willpower.

On february 1, 2016
Peanutz
Mais pourquoi est-il aussi mchant ?

That's because it is difficult to give a definite answer. Roleplay doesn't make everything acceptable, and sometimes the line is thin and subjective between what is against the rules (or here, against the T&Cs) and what is not.

From a gameplay point of view, both characters have to give their consent (the first one by flirting, the other one by doing the thing). From a roleplay point of view, if things go too far in the line of rape jokes, it can be reportable.
On february 4, 2016
Kagaros

Right now on my ship we are mush-free and have gone a long-way. However, the commander says that he will have to go to vacation soon and is bringing up talks of going back to Sol.

This is just a hypothetical question but if the majority of the crew agrees to not go back but the commander does it anyways, with there being no immediate danger to the ship, would this be a reportable offense?
On february 4, 2016
Chime

As far as I know: Yes. If the crew wants to go on, that'd be a harmful return. He's not allowed to shorten your journey or rip you of your chances to find Eden just so he doesn't get a Sold/Starvation/Fatal Depression/Injuries end. Personally I'd say if he really can't stick around any longer (real life does happen after all) he should go stand in a storage for you to sell him and let the next in line take over command. But I'm not sure if that wouldn't be some sort of suicide on his part... either way your hypothetical case sounds reportable.
On february 4, 2016
Aceb

It's harmful return to sol (some people consider is mass murder + pathetic suicide). If He really have to quit, do as Chime said, He should go to storage room and don't play. It should not be count as suicide or destroying game to others as everyone know, real life happens.
On february 4, 2016
TeufelsAdvokat

Regarding that matter one may add that the lenght of the ship plays an important role too:
Stopping to play D4 because of a vacation is report - and sanctionable. People tend to know things like that well in advance and 4 days is much shorter than the average ship.
However, stopping after 2 weeks or longer because of the same reason is within the rules. He couldn't expect the ship to last way longer than average and his crewmates willing to continue past that day.
No idea where the line exactly is (and it may even vary from case to case), but my rule of thumb is to be abled to play at least til day 10.

On february 4, 2016
sperbi

And these people are better than the people who are inactive right from the start, aren't they?
It's not nice if someone is playing though knowing to go on vacation soon, but I wonder whether it is reportable.
On february 4, 2016
sperbi

Ps: that was a comment to TeufelsAdvokat, it would be of course reportable and sanctionable to just return to sol against the crew's wish.
On february 4, 2016
TeufelsAdvokat
sperbiMh. There are people who rarely reach day 10 and won't expect a ship going that long though I fear.
And these people are better than the people who are inactive right from the start, aren't they?
It's not nice if someone is playing though knowing to go on vacation soon, but I wonder whether it is reportable.

It certainly is reportable as I recall a discussion with a mod a while back. Joining a ship for say 1-2 days of gameplay and then going plain inactive spoils the others' game. However players shouldn't be sanctioned, because a ship lasted way longer than expected: The better random ships last up to 3 weeks and Noone should be expected to stop playing that long just for the unlikely possibility of an extraordinary long ship.

And as mentioned I don't know where the line would be drawn, but I'd advise to have at least 10 days to play(casting ticket Sol return). A week(from my estimate average ship lenght) would be somewhat borderline and anything shorter lacks overall decency.

On february 4, 2016
Peanutz
Mais pourquoi est-il aussi mchant ?

There is a difference between 1-2 days and 10 or 15 days. Some ships last 10 days, but there aren't that many ships that reach D15 or more.

If your ship lasts longer than you expected and you realize you won't be able to go on playing due to RL issues, there is nothing you can do. You can't cancel RL commitments because of a game. But you can't decide on your own to end the ship if your crew members want to go on. Whether they decide to keep you alive, sell you or let you live is up to them.

So, to sum up :
- if someone starts a ship while knowing that they will only be able to play for a few days, it is reportable.
- if someone ends a ship in spite of the crew's wishes, it is reportable also.
On february 4, 2016
Flash

How many is "the crew" when it comes to unanimousness? Previously I believe Spazticus stated that it was ~70% but is that still the case?
On february 4, 2016
npfan

There is no hard number. It's just a matter of whether someone who decides to return to Sol had a good reason to do so or not.
On february 4, 2016
Peanutz
Mais pourquoi est-il aussi mchant ?

Or whether those who do not wish to return to Sol have good reasons and are willing to do what it takes. I had a ship on which most of the crew wanted to survive as long as possible, but when it came to dealing with night emergencies, only two of us were awake every night. In the end, we had enough. This was against the wish of the majority, but that same majority wanted something at the expense of two persons. You cannot really sanction someone who doesn't want to exhaust themselves while the rest of the crew sleeps...

On february 14, 2016
spacekadt

The question above is answered well, but there's one bit I want to clarify.

izpodtishkaIf a player's language is in breach of netiquette - it is reportable as well.

A simple "breach of netituette" shouldn't be reported. The SDF isn't here to police the game and make sure that everyone is polite and kind at all times. It should absolutely be reported when it hits a point of abusive or violates the Terms and Conditions of the site.

And just in case I have to be super obvious, the above is not in reference to evalcat's post in any way. I'd report that person in a heartbeat.

Peanutz

Actually, completing mycoscan pre-selection was never a violation of neutral play, as the devs decided not to make it impossible. But that was decided long before it was possible to start with spores.

The neutral play rules are still the same, spores or no spores.

On february 25, 2016
blackgem

Are cuss words (like the F-word, S-word, etc., you would not say in front of your kids) reportable, for instance if a player uses way too many of them when talking to one player?
On february 25, 2016
BadBlanket
blackgemAre cuss words (like the F-word, S-word, etc., you would not say in front of your kids) reportable, for instance if a player uses way too many of them when talking to one player?

Excessive hostility can be reportable, yes... We'd prefer if players try to defuse these sorts of situations themselves but we all know that there are those people who just wont listen. If it's rp that the player is doing, you can ask them to tone it down a bit but it probably wouldn't be recommended to report them (unless they're violating terms and conditions by using slurs and other bigoted words).
On february 26, 2016
spacekadt

To add to what BB said, if they're being used "in the heat of the moment" and in a way that expresses frustration or something like that, it's probably not reportable.

If they're being used to harass someone, it's definitely reportable.

Think about *why* you're reporting someone and that should make it easier. Is it common language that you may not care for personally but is acceptable in the world at large? Or is it abusive and being used to bring morale down on the ship and spoil the journey for the rest of the crew?

Compare your why to Motion Twin's T&C (or the general spoiling rules of Mush - but that's a pretty high threshold if language is all that's at stake, to reach this, it almost always violates the T&C at the same time) and see if it matches.

When it doubt, report. The judges may grumble about not being someone's mother and not here to police the internet (that's my favorite grumble ), but if it doesn't rise to the point of being sanctionable, we clear the report and move on. No harm no foul. (Though don't go reporting everyone that uses the occasional obscenity. That may end up turning around on you eventually.)

On march 4, 2016
Dzanek

Can you get SDF points when you violate rules on a casting?
On march 4, 2016
[6826491]

While you can't hide items prior to selection, holding them in your inventory is treated the same as if you were hiding them - i.e, denying the opportunity for others to pick up said item. This is why Neutral Play rules are still in effect, and why we sanction people for holding non-personal items. The Apron, wrench, weapons in particular, but this is not an exhaustive list. The main reason for the rule is to give no player (and by extension, their team) an unfair advantage at the moment of Mush selection.

Food testing is legal. Forced food testing is illegal. You can't compel any other player to food test. If they do so, it must be voluntary. I often eat twice in order to get things done on the ship; in cases like that, the AP is going toward countering an immediate threat, and it isn't wasteful. Double eating when you don't need to is discouraged. Ship-wide food testing is discouraged along the same lines, because it's ultimately wasteful. (Some castings don't want their members to food test even on random ships, but there is no SDF rule against doing so, except as defined here.)

And to answer Patryk, yes, if the SDF's rules are violated - extreme griefing of the ship as a human, for example; or, something like flooding the chat with pornographic links. If it breaks the casting's rules only, don't expect us to intervene.
On march 4, 2016
Khyze
DarjusIf you want to - do that . But allot of players don't like this kind of act as its food waste + ruining the game for others.
Forced double eat - Punishable .
Double eat in casting ship - If casting rules allot it . If not don't do that as for that you can be punished by SDF points + kick of a casting.

Spazticus

While you can't hide items prior to selection, holding them in your inventory is treated the same as if you were hiding them - i.e, denying the opportunity for others to pick up said item. This is why Neutral Play rules are still in effect, and why we sanction people for holding non-personal items. The Apron, wrench, weapons in particular, but this is not an exhaustive list. The main reason for the rule is to give no player (and by extension, their team) an unfair advantage at the moment of Mush selection.

Food testing is legal. Forced food testing is illegal. You can't compel any other player to food test. If they do so, it must be voluntary. I often eat twice in order to get things done on the ship; in cases like that, the AP is going toward countering an immediate threat, and it isn't wasteful. Double eating when you don't need to is discouraged. Ship-wide food testing is discouraged along the same lines, because it's ultimately wasteful. (Some castings don't want their members to food test even on random ships, but there is no SDF rule against doing so, except as defined here.)

On march 5, 2016
sperbi

Khyze
The mush testing is not included in the rules since the opinions are widely scattered here, so only enforcing of people to do a mush test / taking that as reason to kill them when they refuse is against the rules.
As you indeed noticed, it makes the mush hunt much more easy if people just do voluntary food tests when they have opportunity. Now people may argue: "But the confirmed human can be turned later, so the test is not helping much anyway".
And yes, that may be the case when mushes are on a ship where they have much chances to convert people / high level /being gold etc.
When many tests are happening on ships with humans protecting themselves well and being careful / mushes have not much opportunity to convert, then the mush hunt is definitely easier afterwards... and the mush may feel pressured/unsafe and so it ends more likely in a bloody rampage.
That's why in some castings it is forbidden and some players try their best to avoid confirming themselves easily also on random ships. So not only because they personally consider easy confirmation against the spirit of the game, but also because it may trigger more likely a rampage.
On march 5, 2016
[6826491]

Regarding Mush Tests:

Any player may ask another player to Mush test themselves, explicitly named as a test or not. "Mush test yourself, or we'll kill you." would not be considered asking, and could fall under sanctionable territory. As noted, you can't force anyone to test themselves.

On the other hand, asking them, "Would you be able to drink a coffee, eat a ration, and take care of these hunters this cycle?" is perfectly acceptable. Not only is it being asked in a way that helps the ship if it's done, but the player being asked can consume in a room not covered by a camera or occupied by another player...such as in the patrol ship. (While this means the humans may not have a log or two of the eating, it is still a way to comply with the request in a way that helps the ship, without explicitly testing oneself.)

To add to this, any player who is asked to test themselves has the right to refuse, regardless of whether they are human or Mush. Their refusal is explicitly allowed, because many players feel that Mush testing can spoil the game. You can't play against your team, though, so here's where a few more rules come into play. It's a fair argument, and so we have some ground rules to make sure this is fair to both sides:

1. Refusing a Mush test is not sufficient evidence to kill a player, on its own. The refusal is just a refusal, and if that is the only evidence that you have, it could be sanctioned if the player is killed. In short, if all you have is a refusal, you need more evidence before you murder them. You also can't report someone just for refusing a Mush test. Combined with more harmful behavior, perhaps - but not on its own.

2. If the human(s) asking already have sufficient evidence to suspect the player before the question is asked, they may kill the player, and this killing is generally not sanctionable. The key point here is that some players might act really suspicious, and asking them to Mush test is a last chance to justify keeping them alive. We check PM logs for discussions like that, and establish whether the killer(s) had just cause to suspect the victim.

The reason for the above rules is to give flexibility to Mush, as well as to humans that don't wish to risk being targets for conversion, or want to avoid triggering a rampage caused by "too many humans being confirmed".

3. It bears repeating, since the question comes up often enough: The Natamy Rifle may ONLY be used against other players for assassinations. Not "tests". It is NOT a tool for testing anyone, and using it with the intent to "test" a player can and will garner a guaranteed sanction, even if the victim is a Mush. If you see this behavior, please report it. If there's enough evidence to justify killing a player, then it is just the means to that end; if you shoot with it, you shoot to kill. The Natamy Rifle can inflict multiple injuries per hit, and the injuries from even one successful hit can cripple or even kill a human. Better be damned sure, if you intend to use it.

If you have anyone on your ship that disputes these rules, or how they are handled, please point them to this post. If they want further clarification, they can send me a Twinoid PM.
On march 5, 2016
Cross

I was just thinking, if everyone do that test then finding the Mush will became something easy... So, i tough it was agaisnt the rules .-.

It's not against the rules but many consider it to be poor form for just that reason.

And if i said, "Hey could you eat two bananas?" That will be forced? or i cant mention it? or we can only tell when we do?

You can ask them to eat two bananas as long as they're allowed to refuse without being killed for refusing. Some people will flat out say something like, "I refuse to do Mush tests." Some people will come up with any other kind of excuse so they can refuse while remaining In Character. Either way, the polite thing to do is to accept their refusal and move on, or even more polite not to ask in the first place.
On march 5, 2016
blackgem

What if a player asks another player (i.e. me) to DTT for morale sake, and I refuse. Is that considered playing against human team, or does it fall under the realm of consent? If there are 3 players on a ship and 2 of one gender are about to die of morale loss, and the one of the other gender refuses, is that playing against the team? Maybe I'm not being clear here.

If the human player's only means of survival is DTT at that moment, and the only person available to do it with refuses, is that refusal sanctionable ?
On march 5, 2016
[6826491]

Potentially, yes; but it will of course vary from case to case. Motive is highly important here.

If there is clearly no threat of any Mush remaining, then the only reasons to justifiably refuse would be a lack of AP, or an even greater emergency requiring the player's attention. It would be rather selfish to refuse, and then go work on the Mad Kube, for example. (That would almost certainly get sanctioned, if reported.)

Granted, this is not a guarantee that any refusal would garner a sanction. Just bear in mind that a refusal could be seen as a case of, "you didn't kill them with your bare hands, but you left them to die". Would you accept a Shrink refusing to Comfort someone, knowing that the Shrink had AP to spare, and was the only morale source remaining? Probably not, I'd guess.
On march 5, 2016
blackgem

Well, the thing is my morals prohibit me. I would NOT 'do it' with anyone in RL whom I didn't have a relationship with. And I won't in Mush. If that gets me a saction, no.
On march 5, 2016
BadBlanket
blackgemWell, the thing is my morals prohibit me. I would NOT 'do it' with anyone in RL whom I didn't have a relationship with. And I won't in Mush. If that gets me a saction, no.

Okay. Let us put you into the universe of MUSH. Humanity is cursed with a happiness bar. One that decreased every day without it being the fault of the individual. A bar that only specific things can fill. You are saying you would much rather watch someone die (In a process that isn't their fault) rather than bite the bullet? Especially since the process takes half a second? In addition, you're part of a crew who have been sent to save all of humanity and you would jeopardize such for your morals?

There's a time to rp realistically and be a character with morals then there's a time where you have to balance it with the mechanics of the game. You can't hinder your ship on the basis of RP reasons.

If I understood correctly, I think you mentioned this being the fact that your real world morals prohibit you from having VERY fake relations in a video game? If I understood that correctly then I find it interesting that you have no issues with killing in a video game. =P The line is drawn when the lights go out!
On march 5, 2016
[6826491]
blackgemWell, the thing is my morals prohibit me. I would NOT 'do it' with anyone in RL whom I didn't have a relationship with. And I won't in Mush. If that gets me a saction, no.

RP is never a justifiable reason to play against your team. In this case, your justification comes dangerously close enough to sounding like an RP justification. Even if those are your personal morals, and I'm not suggesting otherwise, what happens to your character is not what happens to you, personally. If that were the case, gamers would be the largest demographic of serial killers (and their victims) on the planet. There would be far fewer of us if that were the case.

You separate what your character does from what you personally might do. Ever kill another player, in any game? Mush is a PvP game, after all. If you morally refuse to kill any character, under any circumstances, then in a situation in which it's just you alone against one or more Mush, you'd surrender - which is explicitly against the rules. Refusing to kill anyone might make sense if you have doubts about whether the killing is justified, or if you're Ian. (Even I've made kills as Ian, in desperate circumstances.) But if there's a mutated Mush, and you outright refuse to help kill that Mush...well, let's just say that falls under playing against the team.

What you're suggesting is in many ways worse than surrendering; it's suggesting that if you're the only morale source left for another player, you'd let them die rather than try to maintain their morale. I can basically guarantee I'd sanction someone who gave that particular justification, and I would deny an appeal made on those grounds.

You are entitled to your morals. You are not entitled to play against your team due to those morals, nor are you entitled to avoid any negative consequences of said action.
On march 5, 2016
BadBlanket

I should also add that "doing the thing" doesn't necessarily have to mean having sex. Yes, someone could end up pregnant but there's always an rp workaround to things. If it really bothers you, for some reason, then discuss it with your "partner" in-game and I'm sure they'll either rp around it with you or not even give a crap one way or the other.

"Janice and Roland killed the lights and then the strange noises started... A few minutes later, the lights went back on. They seemed in great spirits afterwards."

Janice turns out the lights... Then starts making farting noises! Roland giggles like a toddler!

"Gioele and Eleesha killed the lights and then the strange noises started... A few minutes later, the lights went back on. They seemed in great spirits afterwards."

Gioele Flicks off the lights and starts making spooky ghost noises! You don't feel great... Your head is spinning, you feel confused, stressed, and anxious. You should see a Shrink. Eleesha has picked up a psycholigical illness: 2spooked.

Sometimes you have to deal with the game mechanics by being creative. If they get pregnant, well, it's just a sign of the two becoming best friends. Doesn't HAVE to mean pregnancy. I'd feel more sad if my best friend was killed than if some random schmuck was killed, right?
On march 5, 2016
[6384940]

This thread discusses similar problem and solutions at some part.
Also, you can, well, get into the relationship before that (although in some cases it's impossible, I know). You've been on the same ship and handled hardhips together, this brings people closer.
On march 5, 2016
blackgem
BadBlanket

Okay. Let us put you into the universe of MUSH. Humanity is cursed with a happiness bar. One that decreased every day without it being the fault of the individual. A bar that only specific things can fill. You are saying you would much rather watch someone die (In a process that isn't their fault) rather than bite the bullet? Especially since the process takes half a second? In addition, you're part of a crew who have been sent to save all of humanity and you would jeopardize such for your morals?

There's a time to rp realistically and be a character with morals then there's a time where you have to balance it with the mechanics of the game. You can't hinder your ship on the basis of RP reasons.

If I understood correctly, I think you mentioned this being the fact that your real world morals prohibit you from having VERY fake relations in a video game? If I understood that correctly then I find it interesting that you have no issues with killing in a video game. =P The line is drawn when the lights go out!

Spazticus

RP is never a justifiable reason to play against your team. In this case, your justification comes dangerously close enough to sounding like an RP justification. Even if those are your personal morals, and I'm not suggesting otherwise, what happens to your character is not what happens to you, personally. If that were the case, gamers would be the largest demographic of serial killers (and their victims) on the planet. There would be far fewer of us if that were the case.

You separate what your character does from what you personally might do. Ever kill another player, in any game? Mush is a PvP game, after all. If you morally refuse to kill any character, under any circumstances, then in a situation in which it's just you alone against one or more Mush, you'd surrender - which is explicitly against the rules. Refusing to kill anyone might make sense if you have doubts about whether the killing is justified, or if you're Ian. (Even I've made kills as Ian, in desperate circumstances.) But if there's a mutated Mush, and you outright refuse to help kill that Mush...well, let's just say that falls under playing against the team.

On march 5, 2016
[6826491]

It is upsetting to me that you'd be willing to play against your team, to let another player die, because your moral code abhors the notion of even a fictional act. If the reverse situation were true, and your character had zero morale, with DTT as your only means of gaining morale, we could slap you with a Pathetic Suicide sanction if you allowed yourself to die a strictly preventable death.

You are certainly entitled to your morals. However, if your morals cause you to break the rules of the game by playing against your team, then the SDF has a problem with that, and will act accordingly. It is not the fault of any other players that you have your own personal moral code, and it is not their responsibility to be subjected to it.

If all of this is a real serious problem for you, perhaps you are right, and this isn't the game for you.

On march 5, 2016
[6826491]

As I already stated, this is a PvP/survival game. You know that, because you can't possibly win as a human unless the Mush are eliminated. You know that for the humans, they will be forced to kill the Mush when found; you're saying YOU won't kill, so then we must imply that if you are the only player active to stop a rampage, you probably won't do it. We must further imply that you'd be accepting of others killing on your behalf, as long as YOU don't get your hands dirty. Killing by proxy is still killing.

As a Mush, you need to convert the humans to your side, kill them all, or infiltrate Sol/Eden. This would also run counter to your moral code, if you're selected as a Mush. I'll note that if you actively hinder your team as a Mush, that can also lead to a sanction. Refusing to kill humans could certainly count under that rule, if you're discovered and the team decides to rampage.

You also know that the situations on ships often become desperate, and as I already stated, allowing another player to die a preventable death strictly falls under playing against your team. If you are morally unwilling to do whatever it takes to keep your team surviving and advancing, you need to find another game to play.

On may 2, 2016
[9338706]

Hmm, kind of a weird question but I would like to know why aren't inactive players reportable but people who suicide are? To me they both hurt the ship equally and the former is even more annoying because they are receiving xp for literally doing nothing. On my current ship, there are 7 inactive players (this is not an exaggeration).

I know that the SDF doesn't want to punish these players but this pretty creates an enviroment of "Oh well i don't have enough time to play the game or want to; so i'm just gonna farm xp". Because basically this is what's happening as far as i'm concerned.
On may 2, 2016
Peanutz
Mais pourquoi est-il aussi mchant ?

Because basically this is what's happening as far as i'm concerned. You're assuming too much. You do not know what these players think, what is happening in their life, how long they have been playing. So why would you decide that they can't be anything but xp farmers ?

The aim of the SDF is to punish those who harm the game deliberately, and just as in any justice system, you cannot punish someone without a proof that they are guilty. Now, as opposed to regular players, we have access to more information about crew members. Most reports for so-called "xp farming" are cleared for several possible reasons : most of the time, those players are beginners who tried the game but did not like it, people who had real life troubles or internet problems, or even people who were not inactive but were accused of inactivity. When there is proof of real xp farming, then the player can be punished, but that's a minority. Idle griefers, who jump only in order to be inactive, are punished too. But again, that's an exception.
On may 2, 2016
[3350190]

Hello

How many cycles do i have to wait so i can report someone from holding an item before the ship is full
do i have to ask them to drop it? or can i just report them from getting a hold onto such item

Also is there a way for me to see how many reports i have against me? (i want to know what i did wrong)

On may 2, 2016
Aceb
Moscobitch

Hello

How many cycles do i have to wait so i can report someone from holding an item before the ship is full
do i have to ask them to drop it? or can i just report them from getting a hold onto such item

Also is there a way for me to see how many reports i have against me? (i want to know what i did wrong)

First, before You report, try to talk to such person. If there's no response but player have did something after being mentioned, You can feel free to report broken rule.

You will get a message if there's something against You.
On may 2, 2016
[8744424]

1) Some players aren't aware of the neutral play rule, so yes, it's better to ask them to drop stuff and explain why it's not right to hog items prior the selection. But you can just send the report as well and let judges decide.
There's no such thing as a defined amount of cycles after which holding items is concidered to be against the rules - technically, it is not allowed to hold them at all - only move. But then again - maybe a player is just new and didn't know/forgot to drop the object in question and will fix that next time he logs in to check the game.
I, personally, prefer asking first, unless the player is obviously experienced and the object they grab is weapons/armor/scooter.
2) You can't see how many reports have been sent against you or what they were, unless you got a sanction for them (the amount of points is displayed on the My account->My Settings page, alongside with info aboud gold days and such, if I'm not mistaken).
On may 2, 2016
[3350190]

Thank you both, new question.

Can you report someone from doing a NERON project without consulting with the crew? (even before mush selection)
On may 2, 2016
sperbi
Moscobitch

Thank you both, new question.

Can you report someone from doing a NERON project without consulting with the crew? (even after mush selection)

If you believe it was done out of ill intentions and you were harmed critically by it, yes. If you see it done by a newbie, that will be cleared anyway, so don't bother to report it. Also you may wait out eventually, whether the player did it because of being mush.
And if there was no loss of a really important project it is probably also not worth to report.
A good example of when you should report it:
One mush stays with a critical item in Pasisphae, you work hard together to finish magnetic net, but someone finished a crap project instead though it was communicated with everyone how important that project is...

In other cases it may also depend how often/repeatedly the person is showing such behaviour on ship (will player always not listen to crew, working on wrong projects?)
On may 2, 2016
[3350190]
sperbiAlso you may wait out eventually, whether the player did it because of being mush.

I forgot to edit the after, i meant before mush selection, the person just completed the project without even notifying which where the other 2 projects aviable and i doubt is newbie
On may 2, 2016
sperbi
MoscobitchI forgot to edit the after, i meant before mush selection, the person just completed the project without even notifying which where the other 2 projects aviable and i doubt is newbie

Did you ask about the other 2 projects? Eventually they were not worth to finish anyway. Would also be good if someone on your ship already saw the other available projects, otherwise it is difficult to claim the person was harming you...since you just don't know it.
Maybe observe that person how they behave in future actions and decide afterwards whether to send report or not, when having some more grounded believing the person is griefing.
On may 3, 2016
spacekadt

The short answer is that it comes down to intentions. If the person did it out of belief that they were working for the good of the ship, they'll be cleared. Even if it wasn't what the crew wanted. The SDF isn't here to enforce optimal play, we're here to enforce the rules as they're written, but by Motion Twin and the additional rules set forth by SDF. The player would only be sanctioned if it's clear that they were playing against their team.
On may 31, 2016
FredyC

Umm, sorry, but what is proper way of reporting someone after ship has finished?

It's this ship: http://mush.twinoid.com/theEnd/9710

We were doing somewhat fine and suddenly Kuan-Ti decided to hack our way to Sol without getting confirmation from anyone. First I thought he was Mush, but as you can see he wasn't. Please make that guy responsible, this wasn't cool

On may 31, 2016
[1820396]

First of all, I'm not sure it was actually Kuan Ti who hacked the command terminal and returned the ship to Sol. This action leaves mark in character's history (something along the line "You took control of command terminal" ) and there isn't anything like that there. Also, his last words seem pretty upset about the return, too.

Generally, you can report the player after the ship ended in the same way as during the ship - just click on some relevant message in chat and choose report button - but only before you confirm your own last words. After that, it's no longer possible and you can just hope that someone else does it.
On may 31, 2016
FredyC
Patches1984Generally, you can report the player after the ship ended in the same way as during the ship - just click on some relevant message in chat and choose report button - but only before you confirm your own last words. After that, it's no longer possible and you can just hope that someone else does it.

Yea, before confirming I was almost convinced that he was the Mush because our hunting was rather weak so I wasn't completely sure to file report.

You might be right, it seems that Commander Chao actually did it, in that case he might be the one I want to report. I was Terrence there and I definitely disagreed with going Sol, yet he did it without asking.
On may 31, 2016
[1820396]

For next time, I recommend to look at the end page of the ship before confirming your last words, so you know if the potential griefer is mush or not. It's possible, just click on your account and as long as the whole ship is concluded, you should be able to access the end page like the end pages of any other of your past ships.

In cases of doubt, reports are generally fine, it is up to judges whether it is also sanctionable.

apart from this, RP should be separated by gameplay, so Gioele overdid it if it is right what you are saying and can be reported (but got also already some punishment already by being killed ^^). KT's reaction may just be self defense and therefore he probably will get no sanction, but maybe too harsh reaction still, not sure whether it is worth the trouble to check a KT report though.
also it all depend how much emotionally involved both parties were, seems to me like it slowly became more and more worse and a personal conflict in the end and no griefing against ship.
On june 6, 2016
BadBlanket

... Basically report it and we'll check through it. If the time stamps indicate that Kuan Ti had time to think about it and realize he wasn't in any real danger then killing Gioele would likely be reportable. If Kuan Ti acted right after getting attacked then it may have been self defense. As for reporting Gioele, I believe he got his punishment.
On june 6, 2016
Peanutz
Mais pourquoi est-il aussi mchant ?

RP is fine as long as it is not unpleasant for the other players. It does not allow you to be too aggressive verbally, for instance, unless you make it very clear that it's your character speaking to the other characters, not a player talking to other players. Remember that some people are more sensitive than others, and that feeling attacked can be unpleasant in a game, even if it wasn't the purpose.

Of course, RP does not allow murder either, or dangerous actions, or any action that can harm the ship in any way. Punching someone can be fun, if it is clearly part of roleplay and if all characters involved are aware that it's only RP (it does not hurt to make an OOC comment to confirm it). And of course, punching a healthy person once is fine, but attacking someone who is wounded or punching several times is not fine at all.

Overreacting to RP can be reportable, but if the situation was not clearly RP or was excessive, if the player felt attacked, then murder can be understandable. Again, it depends a lot on the situation, on what was said and how, on what happened...
On june 7, 2016
sperbi
sperbi

In cases of doubt, reports are generally fine, it is up to judges whether it is also sanctionable.

apart from this, RP should be separated by gameplay, so Gioele overdid it if it is right what you are saying and can be reported (but got also already some punishment already by being killed ^^). KT's reaction may just be self defense and therefore he probably will get no sanction, but maybe too harsh reaction still, not sure whether it is worth the trouble to check a KT report though.
also it all depend how much emotionally involved both parties were, seems to me like it slowly became more and more worse and a personal conflict in the end and no griefing against ship.

Just in case, someone got confused by me:

Judging can never happen without looking at situation carefully. The short answer should just have been to report in case of doubts and everything else can only be seen later, taking all information into account. Examples I mentioned must not be truth and a killing is always a something to look closely at, whether it was justified. well, I thought my uses of "maybe", "may", "if", "seems" were enough to show I was just speculating, but someone seemed to take it all as a written - in - stone answer.
On june 17, 2016
Sachiko

Is killing your Mush partner in order to "look human" and "gain the trust of the human crew" against the sdf rules?

I personally think it is but other people on my ship think it's acceptable...
On june 17, 2016
[8281990]

Only if it benefits the mush team - usually when the humans want to kill your partner anyway and you can seize the opportunity to gain some trust. Which means you had better have planned it ahead of time with your partner. You can't just turn on them to save your own skin.

I remember a game where a beta Eleesha selfishly turned on her alphas immediately after conversion, in hopes of being able to declare the ship "mush free" and sneak one home for the team. But it wasn't discussed among the mush team and she was definitely reported for it. (It also failed, because the human team was too smart to fall for it.)
On june 17, 2016
Peanutz
Mais pourquoi est-il aussi mchant ?

You can kill your partner if they are already discovered. In some cases, you have to kill them if the crew know that you are online and have the ability to help, because it would look suspicious not to do it. You also have to say something if you walk in on your partner extracting a spore or doing a mush action, or you would be suspected if you walked through the room and did not alert anyone. But of course that does not mean that you can't warn your partner and try to come up with a plan to delay their death or rampage.

Sometimes the mush can also decide to sacrifice one of them. That's acceptable too, as long as they all agree, especially the victim, of course.

What is not acceptable is to denounce your partner without any reason, or attract too much attention to them. Killing them out of the blue is not acceptable either.

On july 3, 2016
[8744424]

What clearly shouldn't be reported: personal offences and behaviour that isn't anyhow against the rules. If it seems that a player did break them, if they were harming the team, I don't see any problem in reporting, to be honest.
You don't have to know that for 100% - sometimes you just don't have enough evidence as a player, for example.
But I'd suggest trying to explain those players what they did wrong and why that is wrong, while they're still on ship before filling a report (if there is such an opportunity). I'd say that's an important thing to do since 1) they really might not be knowing they're doing anything wrong (newish players or those who came back after long hiatus) and 2) Many players don't understand what they're punished for when they recieve a sanction and don't try to ask as well, so explaining should help in getting through this part.
On july 3, 2016
spacekadt
Veren

of course i asked if it worth to be reported, what else in a topic called "ask the SDF"

seing what juges answer sometimes i know we really don't have the same point of view about what to report or not, and that's why i asked

If you re-read your post, you'll see that there really is no question there... much less a clear question. It would truly help everyone if you included your actual question in your posts so we don't have to guess what you're asking... or whether you're actually asking anything at all and didn't just accidentally post in the wrong place.

That said, I think the question has been pretty well answered at this point. In general, if you believe the rules to have been broken, report the player. It also doesn't hurt to actually ask the player before reporting (if you can) to clarify intent when/if you're confused.

[1765606]

On july 11, 2016
spacekadt
PunfAre you allowed to finish the pilgred and return to sol (via hacking) before mush selection? Or would that violate neutral play rules?

It actually has nothing to do with neutral play.

However, this issue is being actively discussed right now among the mods and judges. As soon as something is decided one way or the other, we'll make sure it's updated in the rules post (which is due for an update anyway).

On july 11, 2016
blackgem

Besides, in the meanwhile it ruins the game for several other people. People who don't get on that ship, and those on the ship who disagreed with rushing PILGRED and returning home pre-selection.
On july 14, 2016
spacekadt
PunfAre you allowed to finish the pilgred and return to sol (via hacking) before mush selection? Or would that violate neutral play rules?

So now that we've discussed and put a new version of the rules out, the one that particularly applies here is:

A harmful return to Sol (without crew consensus or while the ship is still early in its voyage, for instance) is not permitted. This includes pre-selection returns that amount to giving up on the voyage.

For a full and up-to-date version of the rules, you can see the SDF Rules and Information posts in both Advice and Discussion forums (they're the same in both places - we just wanted to make sure they were easily found for everyone).
On july 14, 2016
blackgem

Thanks! That makes it a lot easier to link rules to rulebreakers on my ship.

On july 14, 2016
[8744424]

I'd like to note that "everybody agrees" is a very iffy phrasing when it comes to pre-selection. Because, ahem, pre-selection = before everyone wakes up from cryo.

So basically 1) you're trying to make a decision for those who haven't yet awakened, Dzanek, and also 2) there're people who join the ship, let's say, in the morning before running off to work, and start acting in-game several cycles later, when being back, so you're, very likely, trying to make a decision for those, who might have liked to speak, but were not around to do so when "everybody" agreed.
On july 14, 2016
Dzanek

I meant that everybody awaken, it's really less than half and we're losing the hope for those awaken because so far 2 people has awoken and both of them are new players who made tutorial and seem not to know what's going in game. We're in progress to fix the PILGRED but this ship has been reported.
