On july 14, 2016
Chime

I don't think arguing about it after they just updated the rules yesterday will change them but the "the people that haven't woken up yet had no say" part isn't understandable to me either. I understand why this kind of sol return is not wanted and therefore forbidden but that reasoning doesn't work for me.

Sure, izpodtishka is right about the phrasing it wouldn't be everyone agreeing but everyone awake at the moment. But technically there would be no players behind the characters still sleeping and it should make no difference to them once they jump whenever they end up on that ship or another (unless they want to meet up with someone already on board but that person would not agree to return then). So no harm done to them.

But let's say everyone awake agrees, you start fixing pilgred and a new person wakes up shortly before they finish it. That person doesn't agree and you are back to waiting for the rest to wake up with an almost done pilgred, a nice present for the future mush. And then there's a story-wise flaw to returning to Sol pre-selection: you win if you return mush free, but you are not mush free. Your mush is just sleeping, you'll land in your rebel base, he'll wake up and infiltrate it and humanity is doomed: you lose. So I get the rule, but not the "the people that haven't woken up yet had no say"-explanation.

And Patryk, I think that you, having proven knowledgeable of the ban on it by asking these questions, would definitely get into trouble... if your newbies are active try to teach them rather than sigh at their lack of knowledge active newbies are the next generation, we need them.
If they look promising, tell them there are better ships out there and bribe them with cookies to stay.

On july 14, 2016
[8744424]

I can't speak for the SDF regarding the matter in question, but, since everything else is already well-said by Chime, I'd like to add to the "no say" part from the perspective of that very player, who wakes up after those who have joined before and made the choice, then (yes, let's say I am that player): people decide to break the game before it started (that already is the issue on it's own, for a multi-player one, right?) I join the broken game, a game that I was going to play, but now I can't - because either they're going to end it regardless of what I say or do (goodbye gold day or 2, all the time I've spend for coordinating with friends, and whatnot else) or I am supposed to be forcing them to play (eh?) with an almost finished Pilgred. Forcing people to play is ridiculous on it's own, and there's not much "playing" in a game with almost finished Pilgred since mush can finish it with a finger snap.

And the part that I, personally, can't understand, as a player: you (hypothetical you, not referring to anyone here) either want to play a game or you don't. If you don't want - then just don't play, if you do - you're welcome on board of Daedalus. But Mush is the kind of game where you can't choose the starting conditions and it's RNG-based (=> you might start with conditions that are not perfect, more or less), so the more exact question would be "do you want to play this particular game?" My answer would be "yes" and so, here I am, joining the game, but.. well, I can't play it, apparently. And since I can't do anything about it, I would only like to ask in that situation all those people: guys, if you didn't want to play this game - why did you join the ship then?
On july 14, 2016
Kenik

I should throw my hat into the ring I guess.
A lot of people just want to play the game, get to Sol, Get to Eden, or at least have fun on the way to exploding.
The problem is an early Sol return keeps people from being able to join the game. It may seems small, "they can just jump on a new ship". But the fact that this process slows the filling of ships in general can't be ignored. Some of these players will be asleep when it starts. And if any of them are roleplayers, now they have the knowledge that they just doomed Earth by that perspective.

Also Dzanek it doesn't become a crime when it's reported, it's a crime when it's committed. It causes damage no matter what, even if that damage is just setting a bad example.

On july 14, 2016
Peanutz
Mais pourquoi est-il aussi mchant ?

Ok, let's make it simple and stop that discussion that is going nowhere. People who launch a ship want to play Mush. It should be obvious, and yet it seems that it is not. "Playing Mush" means playing the actual game, fully, and one of its the main components is mush hunting or being mush. By ending a ship early, you deprive other people of the possibility to play the game as they expected to play it and as it should be played.


the jump had already been planned.Players have their own goals and everybody sees victory in another way That excuse is total nonsense. You can't start a game of soccer and decide that your goal is to score against your own team. You can't launch a Mush ship and decide to change the aim of the game. If you want to play differently, just launch casting ships.

Are there any thread necromancy rules for this forum?
On july 21, 2016
spacekadt
N_FakerAre there any thread necromancy rules for this forum?

Use your best judgement. If the discussion looks to be long dead and fully discussed, don't necro it. If there's a hanging question that you also have and the conversation is relevant, it makes sense to necro it.
On july 27, 2016
N_Faker

Which quarantine reasons are causing the most appeals?

Will you be notified of any SDF points attached to your account?

I'm asking mostly in case there are possibly obscure or easily missed rules which leaves the quarantined confused as to why they ended up being punished.
On july 27, 2016
spacekadt

I won't discuss appeals and reasons in any detail - only to say that the vast majority of appeals are because the person doesn't believe they did anything wrong as opposed to not understanding what the sanction was for.

As for notification, yes, the system will send you a twinoid message if you receive a sanction. It will give you the reason for the sanction, the number of points earned on this sanction as well as your overall points.

On august 4, 2016
N_Faker

Considering that non-English speakers should be reported. Should mute players also be reported?
More often than not a mute person will likely be someone not fluent or even all that familiar with English, should these people be reported?
On august 4, 2016
spacekadt

Unless they're actually breaking a rule somewhere, no. It is a social game and we do encourage people (strongly, at that) to be active and chat with other crewmembers, there's no rule that they MUST participate in chat. The vast majority of mute players are new players that aren't quite comfortable yet.
On august 4, 2016
Peanutz
Mais pourquoi est-il aussi mchant ?

I would advise to try and talk to them in private first. I just ended a ship in which Janice never talked (I don't think she ever said one word in the main channel) and Chun barely talked. It turns out that they were both French.

But while Janice never talked and never listened (except when Hua started talking to her in French in private), Chun did her best. She did not speak much, but sometimes she did. And she also read the conversations and reacted. For instance, when we talked about placing the mycoalarms in the mush-hunting channel, Chun almost immediately said "I'll do it", and yet she hadn't said a word before.

I ended up reporting Janice, because she did not even try, she probably did not speak a word of English, and we could not count on her. She just comforted people at random since she did not know who needed it, she did not activate plasma shield or change the Bios settings... But I did not report Chun.

I also remember a Kuan Ti who never, ever talked, and we were all convinced that he was not French (it was a French ship). And then I addressed him directly after a few days, and he replied with a full paragraph in perfect French.

In short, you can't always assume that a mute player is not a native speaker, and it also depends on whether the lack of communication hurts the ship or not.
On august 4, 2016
N_Faker

As I'm gathering it. It will depend on the severity and situation, but some cases should be reported?
On august 4, 2016
Peanutz
Mais pourquoi est-il aussi mchant ?

Most cases should not be reported, because you can't know if they don't speak English, if they are bad players, if they are new and a little lost, if they have time to play but not to communicate...

You should report if the lack of communication has an impact and if you are sure that the player does not speak English (because someone who joins a game in a language that they don't speak knows that they won't be able to play it properly and that it will have a negative impact on the ship). We knew that the Janice I mentioned was French because we tried to talk to her in that language and replied ; and her total lack of communication caused several problems.
On august 4, 2016
[7024616]

So there is no problem if I'm in a ship trying to speak in a good english every time? Cause it's obvious I'm not from the server and I'm afraid that if I write something in the wrong way and you don't understand me I can get reported.
So you can only be reported if you talk in your own language in other server if it's not a private channel with people that talk your language?
PD: anyway, I talk a lot, and I like this server, so I would like to be nice to this people and don't break your rules.
On august 4, 2016
N_Faker

If items disappear pre-mush selection and you don't know who hid it. Should a random person/yourself be the target of the report with the explanation in the report itself?

Or should the report not be filed at all if you don't know?
On august 4, 2016
[1820396]

1) Just to be sure: It's impossible to hide item pre-selection, it was disabled in one of earlier season changes. It's either held in someone's inventory or just moved to another room.

2) Judges can't judge another person then the one the report was filed for. Mods can do this, but this is reserved for really serious and/or repeated offenses. This means that the report would end up cleared, unless you luckily hit the right person.
Definitely don't report every person on board! This way you might end up sanctioned for report abuse and wasting judges' time.

Best course of action in such situation is to wait with report. Call out the person that took the item in general chat, if they just forget to put it down, they probably will do so. Explain that it's violation of neutral play and spoiling. If still no one confesses to holding it in inventory, just wait until the item shows up - holder might die sooner or later or some kind of action will give them up. Then you can report.

All in all, you can wait with your report literally to the end of the ship. Report won't be judged sooner, anyway, and you will have more informations to report the right person for right violation of rules.
On august 4, 2016
spacekadt
franfran2424So there is no problem if I'm in a ship trying to speak in a good english every time? Cause it's obvious I'm not from the server and I'm afraid that if I write something in the wrong way and you don't understand me I can get reported.
So you can only be reported if you talk in your own language in other server if it's not a private channel with people that talk your language?
PD: anyway, I talk a lot, and I like this server, so I would like to be nice to this people and don't break your rules.

Basically, what we ask of people is to be understandable and to *try*. Someone that's obviously using Google Translate runs the risk of being sanctioned, but someone that obviously isn't a native speaker but can still get their points across and communicate is fine.
On august 7, 2016

N_FakerWill a suicide go under the "self-sacrifice" exclusion of the suicide rule, if you know you won't have access to mush for an extended period while having a vital role(e.g Commander).

Suicide is never na option. If You know that You will not have access to mush (because life happens), just don't log in. If You won't log in a day, title will stay at next person after You.

If you don't go to a storage, you still can be sold, but in longer time.

On august 7, 2016
Aceb
N_Faker

Self sacrifice suicides are allowed. They have an absolute requirement to be for the betterment of your team . I'm merely asking if this is such a situation.

Staying inactive for a prolonged period as the Commander can doom ships. If the crew agrees to kill me/let me die there should be no problems, or?

Self sacrifice suicides are very rare things and yes, they can happen, but they're only exceptions.

Just go inactive, dang it. You can't suicide. Just inform your crew about unability to play for sometime and let them decide for whatever they might do with You. You can increase their odds of peaceful approach and idle in storage.

On august 7, 2016
spacekadt
N_FakerWill a suicide go under the "self-sacrifice" exclusion of the suicide rule, if you know you won't have access to mush for an extended period while having a vital role(e.g Commander).

I really don't think there's a straightforward answer to this. If you know you're about to go inactive, talk to your crew and see what they think the best course of action is.

Beyond that, the rule very clearly states that surrender is not permitted. It does not go on to say "except in cases of (insert reason here)."

Is there a chance you'll be back semi-soon? Let the title pass and then maybe you can come back and continue to help the crew. If the title isn't passing quickly enough, the crew could kill someone to make the title pass if there's an emergency.

There are ways to approach the situation that aren't suicide - which makes me extremely hesitant to go against one of the few core rules of the game.
On august 7, 2016
N_Faker

I will likely not have any chances of getting on at all after that point, with a period of 6-7 days.
Inactivity in my case may mean 13 cycles, which is cripplingly long to wait for inactivity.
I'm discussing it with my crew presently, not many have given their input yet though.

I won't surrender or abandon my ships, not willingly at least. I would just want to make it easier for my crew to continue should it be called for.
On august 7, 2016
sperbi

Just a hint: With hacker kit and staying logged in (yes, not always possible, but sometimes, at least for some time), people with hacker kit is able to do ship movements even when many movings are necessary.
It should be possible long enough until you get inactive status and the next person in line gets commander title.
I guess only a very specific situation (example: There are no pilots, the whole crew is just working on pilgred and escaping from hunters until pilgred is done, the time to wait until commander titel passes woudl be defeat of humans, furthermore hacker kit is not available anymore) would justify such a suicide for a quicker title passing and therefore chance for a human win (suicide happens in best interest of your team then and only after all other options seem not possible).

Your situation doesn't sound as if such a measure is the only way out though and your team has probably still many ways left to deal with your absence accordingly without you needing to suicide.
And just saving some aps for the human team is as reason just not good enough.

DurrDudeIs it legal to AFK just because you hate your current ship(full of inactives) but check back often so see if you died yet

That's treated as a surrender, and is strictly against the rules. You're not allowed to just "give up", no matter how much you like or dislike your crew.
DurrDude

On august 21, 2016
BadBlanket

I've been on many doomed ships that I've helped turn into a Cinderella story. By going AFK you become part of the problem that you're trying to avoid. There will always be people trying on a ship, no matter how doomed. By leaving those people behind you are worse than the inactives that caused you to do it. They likely just didn't want to play the game. You, however, would be actively abandoning people.

If a ship is as bad as you think it is then it wont be a long ship, regardless. You might be wrong, though. You, alone, might make all the difference in sending the ship back home mush free. Try to make the best of a bad situation. Go down honorably or get the ship home heroically.

On august 24, 2016
[6826491]

If you already left your last words, then you've lost the ability to report anyone. The last opportunity to report a player is from that page.

If in doubt, you can access your previous ships before leaving your last words, here. If you've already done that, then report away, and we'll take a look. If you already left your last words, the only thing you can hope for is that another player filed a report against that player.
On august 28, 2016
Alyarin

Are humans and Mush allowed to cooperate in any way? For instance, deals mutually beneficial to both sides?
On august 28, 2016
Aceb
AlyarinAre humans and Mush allowed to cooperate in any way? For instance, deals mutually beneficial to both sides?Impet

Cooperation is not allowed.

So long as every player on that ship is trying to get a win for their team (Humans for human win, mush for mush win) there is nothing wrong with

- The Mush infect and kill all but one human
- They are revealed to all be Mush
- They keep the human alive as a Hostage, so that NERON doesn't kill them.

Secrecy is NOT required of mush. If you can see a way to get a mush win without secrecy, go for it. Roughly one third of my mush wins occurred after I was known to be mush (Sometimes I died before the humans finished dying, sometimes not). I've had a blast being a known mush and manipulating situations so that I could not be killed yet, or so that it cost so much to kill me right then and there were other urgent priorities that needed doing as much or more than killing me... Rarely I've managed to inconvenience the active humans so greatly that they were mostly defensive. There are strategies involving ceasefire and the capacity limitation of Icarus Bay that can help mush survive after being revealed.

If you have something like 8 active mush and 1 active human, the human probably cannot kill all the mush and get back to sol - but that human has to try. That human will be a pain to keep alive - because only humans get panic attacks - with only one human, that player will get ALL the panic attacks, potentially many per cycle.

This is a problem though:

-They order the human not to attack them, and the human obeys. Finally, they give a few ground-rules such as 'stay out of the lab!'

Humans and mush cannot knowingly cooperate. That human may -choose- to appear to obey while preparing however they are trying to win.

Example: I am your human. I think 'Oh @#$@#, I have 1 move, 0 AP, and there are 8 living mush and me'. You tell me to cooperate and you let me live as human for now, I tell you thank you (maybe report you for inciting spoiling - that is sanctionable of you to do), and use my time to get AP to try and kill you all. I have to - have to - I cannot win while there are mush alive. I know who the mush are. I MUST kill you or die in the attempt. I will not stop trying to kill you (thus I am not sanctionable). I'm not in trouble because you made the deal to me or because I appear to accept it - so long as I try to win for my team. You can be in trouble for offering it.

A very legal way to do this plan:

Keep 1+ humans alive and human, the ones you believe are easiest to trick. They can even be inactives that are kept alive by Janice comforts and medkit fighting off starvation. I recommend keep more than one alive - panic attacks are NASTY when there's only one player getting all of them. Do your very very best to make those humans believe you're all human, and seek Eden together.

On september 14, 2016
Aceb
TsunamiNO. We had good reason to suspect Chao, and Chao had already killed Gioele because this guy said to. I won't report Chao because he was just role playing but this other guy is ruining the game.

Any "random" killing is prohibited. Even if the victim was mush (for example, if You kill someone 1minute after mush selection). Chao can get away with "random" killing sometimes, because He gets glory for this and to kill someone, You have to give some hints, why did You do it. Some players open private channel to explain their reasoning if they don't wanna (or can't) share it with crew.

If You belive that, there was a rule broken, just report and make a clear comment why.


[edit]: or simply, Murderer have to justify his kill by explaining a thing. Killing inactive indeed might be a free kill but reasoning is important here.

Glory is NEVER an acceptable reason for random killing. In fact, there is zero acceptable reason for random kills.

Chao does get some small amount of leeway on his "kill first, ask questions later" type of attitude because that's the character's backstory. But there must be a valid reason for the kill. There is no exception to this rule.
On september 15, 2016
[8744424]

Just for clarification: neither hoping for glory nor RP can serve as the justification for random kills.

It's simply the best way we had (shy of deleting your post) to make the distinction incredibly clear before anyone sees it and starts thinking it's ok for Chao to kill people at random.
On september 18, 2016
[1765606]

Suppose that (let's say Terrence) is found to be at full health and dirty by the medkit. Someone else (let's say Chao) commands him to shower (which is acceptable since being dirty for extended periods benefits the mush), telling him that he will use the medkit after showering to check if he is at full health.

Situation A: Terrence showers, and Chao then finds him to be not at full health and then kills him.
Situation B: Terrence refuses to shower, claiming that it is unacceptable for Chao to force a mush test on him in this way. Chao kills him, claiming that he cannot allow a player to stay dirty for an extended period of time with no reason because this is strong evidence of being mush.

Has either player broken a rule in either of these situations? Does the answer depend on whether or not Terrence actually *is* mush? (Assume Chao is human.)
On september 18, 2016
spacekadt

Either scenario is suspicious enough (either allowing Terrence to stay dirty or Terrence refusing to shower) that I'd be looking at why he's dirty... what did he say to the crew? is it fishy? as a player on the ship, is there a legitimate belief that he's probably a mush?

However, it absolutely is possible to take random damage from showering, as well as picking up the soap. One or the other is fairly plausible, both would be incredibly unlucky, but conceivably possible. While Chao would be well advised NOT to kill someone just for that reason, I'd still look to the questions above to see if there was legitimate belief beyond just not being full health anymore.

Whether Terrence turns out to be mush or not is beside the point.
On september 18, 2016
Peanutz
Mais pourquoi est-il aussi mchant ?

Incredibly unlucky but totally possible if the RNG wants to troll you.

On october 10, 2016
ShuDog

Welp, I've searched and searched and cannot find an answer, so I'll try here. Apologies if I missed something. It's about pre-selection neutral gameplay. This is all before selection started, so if the ship is active I don't think it'll affect anything.

So this ship had the Lizaro Jungle BP, and quite a few active pilots pre-selection. I was planning my sofa-making mission, except someone who had been doing inventory went ahead and dismantled the AD shower. Gioele had paranoid, so there were extra cameras and they were already installed.
The soap was also missing (probably held by a griefer), thus both showers would have cost the same in AP.

I argued that this was *not* a neutral action. I was shouted down by the active members of the crew that mush would "take silent showers in AD" - to which I asked, didn't AD have a camera?? I was not given a straight answer to that one (and didn't have MP to check.) And wasn't that the point exactly? If you become mush, then you just hurt your team and it's not a neutral action. Is that correct?

So which is it? I was given to understand that having the Lizaro Jungle BP meant we could have two showers. Why would dismantling a shower automatically be a neutral action?

(There were other random-killing shenanigans but honestly I'm too lazy to file a report.)

(They also rushed Convenient Sink as the first project, though I honestly have no idea if that's related or not.)
On october 10, 2016
[8744424]

Showering is a private action, so it won't be displayed in the logs regardless of camera being installed or not.

Neutral play is aimed at preventing any of teams, mush or human, getting advantages before the competitive game starts. Meanwhile, players need to do something while ship's still filling and keep the ship in a playable further condition.

Now, taking those points and all the explanations from mods about neutral play on forums into account, I'll try to give an explanation from my point of view and hope to be corrected in case I'm somehow wrong about it.
If no cameras are installed - humans have no place to be safe in, while mush can infect/convert them with no extra efforts, completely unnoticeable, thus placing cameras in dorms at least, and giving them some spots to be safe at - isn't ruining the balance.
If both showers are functional - mush can secretely shower with no chance for getting any evidence about that. With one functioning shower, however, mush can still secretly take a shower, but humans get a minor evidence to work with in their investigation. So balance isn't disrupted in that case as well.

Plus, if things like doing inventory, neutral research, dismantling a shower, building sofa, etc, will be prohibited - 1) what would be left to do that whole time while ship's filling? and 2) if nothing would be done in order to keep the ship afloat, humans are likely to have significant difficulties when it finally fills and the overall condition might be pretty screwed to have a normal game.

The Natamy Rifle may ONLY be used against other players for assassinations. Not "tests" and using it with the intent to "test" a player can and will garner a guaranteed sanction, even if the victim is a Mush.

so you blast a player with it 5 times (it's theoretically possible) and they don't die. Minimum damage would be 5x6 (30) on a mush so they would be dead for sure. Now you're in a situation where you have to ask for help killing a human so you can avoid a sanction?

On october 16, 2016
[8744424]

Err.. Sorry, whut?

If you're shooting someone with a Natamy and they appeared to be human that was lucky enough to survive 5 shots - killing them doesn't make any sense, as you've mentioned yourself.

Sanctions can only be given when you're using it with intent to perform a test, as stated in the quotation, meaning: if you have enough evidence for killing your suspect - well go and kill them, but If you don't have enough evidence for the death sentence and are still in doubt - don't use Natamy for testing them. As simple as that.

On november 8, 2016

On november 8, 2016
spacekadt
factoryman942Would killing all Highly Inactives on a ship, for relatively minor benefits such as Cold Blooded bonus, to reduce targets for Transfer, or because "they're easier to kill" be reportable/sanctionable?

It depends on the circumstances. Does the entire crew agree? How's morale? Since each death is going to hit everyone's morale for -1 point, it could very well kill a large number of crewmates.

I'd say it's certainly reportable. Whether it's sanctionable is up to judges looking at the individual circumstances of the ship and what the crew thought of it.
On november 8, 2016
factoryman942

I feel a need to elaborate; no crewmembers have yet been harmed as a result of this, however signs point towards it going that way. Just wanted to know in advance in case it should happen.
On november 8, 2016
Peanutz
Mais pourquoi est-il aussi mchant ?

It's not just about individual crewmembers' morale, it's about harming the ship and the human team in general. Frankly, I fail to see the benefit of killing all inactives, except if you think that the mush is active and might use them as transfer targets (especially dangerous characters). Apart from that risk, keeping inactives alive does not harm anyone and can have benefits, for instance the chance to trade against something useful or even vital. On the other hand, killing them deprives the ship of that chance, causes morale loss and sometimes serious illnesses (whereas an inactive dying naturally can die of depression and cause no morale loss), and it is also a waste of AP that could be use for more important things. Cold-Blooded is a poor excuse, since it generally takes more than 3 AP to kill someone. To me, killing an inactive is not much better than playing with the kube, since in both cases, there are always more important things to do.

It is, indeed, an awfully disappointing situation. However, reporting system exists for dealing with players who violate the rules - not for punishing "bad play". And clearly not for patching up all the hurt butts

On november 21, 2016
factoryman942

The quarantine system doesn't really discriminate. And I'm quite sure in Die2Nite, if someone were to magically get banned while within a town cough cough gadget cough for whatever reason, they would immediately be removed from said town? Would you complain about that, if they had, to use some example of serious grief there, punched people then hidden at the town gates so as to prevent retaliation?

We get waves of griefers here on occasion. As in, every so often about 3 or 4 people appear on each ship, then start indiscriminately murdering as soon as Mush are selected. Being able to immediately respond to that and prevent them from doing any additional harm to that ship is doubtlessly extremely helpful.

And it sounds like you got banned for something to do with food tests; mush tests're allowed, so long as it is done by choice. Attempting to coerce someone to do one, or killing them for not doing one, is bannable, and a portion of the community considers food testing immediately to be... dishonourable?

i am only trying to get the general idea (to be completely honest i am thinking about moving on to play mush full time and dump D2N, but first i need to know if i would fit in here knowing how things are handled, and i love Fairness and standing up for it so its a Huge deal to me to know this is a fair game)

i will form my question in a better way now that i know a bit more from the 2 replies above (big thanks for your infos guys)

if the Mods know the reason for each ban and can categorize it in lets say for example 4 levels each time they give one:
lvl 1: innocent first mistake (noob ban)
lvl 2: intentional 2nd Report (didnt now noob ban)
lvl 3: occasional Reports (serioes)
lvl 4: Obvious Griefer (Dangerous)
i assume each level have SDF Points:

WHY would there be a system that ruins the game for 15 innocent players who happen to be in the exact ship as the players who get the lvl 1 and lvl 2 bans and get killed in those ships even though the Mods know what those lvl1 and lvl2 did and also know they wont be any threat to a new ship and can be quarantined once the ship ends not in the middle of it?

i am looking at it from my perspective for example joining a ship on sunday and turns out to be higher than average active ship so i decide to buy gold days for bonuses. and on Day 2 or 3 BAM janice or Chun or an Alpha mush are killed due to a ban. , ok if they were Bans of lvl3 and lvl4 i would be ok having them dead. BUT what if they were only lvl 1 or 2 and pose zero threat to this new ship and can get their punishment after this ship is done: then why do i have to suffer for that and spend my gold days and my time in a ship with missing key Character since giving up or suicide is not part of the game and not allowed? isnt it a bit of a lazy system and a more advanced one is better?

and i am not here to change things, only here to decide if this game is for me or not , that is all. not here to debate or suggest either, i will be gone as soon i get the general idea...
On november 21, 2016
Aceb
Dream

thanks for the reply BUT i am talking about a loophole in the ban system. i dont like the idea that its black and while and there is no grey area for quarantines levels.

i am only trying to get the general idea (to be completely honest i am thinking about moving on to play mush full time and dump D2N, but first i need to know if i would fit in here knowing how things are handled, and i love Fairness and standing up for it so its a Huge deal to me to know this is a fair game)

i will form my question in a better way now that i know a bit more from the 2 replies above (big thanks for your infos guys)

if the Mods know the reason for each ban and can categorize it in lets say for example 4 levels each time they give one:
lvl 1: innocent first mistake (noob ban)
lvl 2: intentional 2nd Report (didnt now noob ban)
lvl 3: occasional Reports (serioes)
lvl 4: Obvious Griefer (Dangerous)
i assume each level have SDF Points:

WHY would there be a system that ruins the game for 15 innocent players who happen to be in the exact ship as the players who get the lvl 1 and lvl 2 bans and get killed in those ships even though the Mods know what those lvl1 and lvl2 did and also know they wont be any threat to a new ship and can be quarantined once the ship ends not in the middle of it?

i am looking at it from my perspective for example joining a ship on sunday and turns out to be higher than average active ship so i decide to buy gold days for bonuses. and on Day 2 or 3 BAM janice or Chun or an Alpha mush are killed due to a ban. , ok if they were Bans of lvl3 and lvl4 i would be ok having them dead. BUT what if they were only lvl 1 or 2 and pose zero threat to this new ship and can get their punishment after this ship is done: then why do i have to suffer for that and spend my gold days and my time in a ship with missing key Character since giving up or suicide is not part of the game and not allowed? isnt it a bit of a lazy system and a more advanced one is better?

and i am not here to change things, only here to decide if this game is for me or not , that is all. not here to debate or suggest either, i will be gone as soon i get the general idea...

It works like it works both way. If griefer is about to grief another ship, he gets quarantineed and 15 "innocent" players are "safe" from such "player".

If someone just by very bad plays or being rewared for bad behaviour gets quarantineed on next ship, it's mostly their fault and the rest of the crew can usually manage to live, if it's at beginning.

How much fair it is, depend from the punished person. If it was a griefer, then it's fair for crew to be "saved".
If it was a player with bad behaviour, they can learn from it and others well. No one suspected a thing, right? It happens.

Remember that the actions that this player have done to previous crew, was unfair also. What about them? Because this system it works like it works and people behind it are not a lightning strikes, it hits sooner or later.

I'm speaking from a perspective of person who have lost 2 ships because someone got suddenly quarantined in key moment.

Also the amount of times you encounter a griefer is far and few, most often your problems will be with inactives. (But they hurt the game the same way )
On november 21, 2016
TeufelsAdvokat

Dream: Might help to drop the "ship is ruined, because one/some key characters are missing" way of thinking. On the contrary this may even spice things up a little more.

Besides as far as I can tell the game isn't even designed to be played by 15 players or overly long. After all we only have 7(+1) beds on most ships, rebel bases stop after day 7 and NERON projects are usually completed until D10(well, if they are completed at all.^^)
Also no character is vital for the ship(killing them would mean easy win for the Mush otherwise). There are several morale sources and skills, hunters can be fought with patrollers, turrets or outrunning them for some time, and so on...

The devs obviously expected griefers, inactives, Mush rampages and the like. In fact only a handful of people is required to run a successful ship.

On november 21, 2016
TeufelsAdvokat
Jerms

I'm not 100% sure about this, but most of the time it takes a majority of players from that ship to ban someone, or they had to have a past history of griefing to get quarantined.
Organic Waste is yummy.. I don't know what you're talking about
So the level 1/2 bans don't usually happen because hopefully the crew understands that it was a noob mistake and not purposeful.

We had a beginner Eleesha print day 3 (I believe soon after mush selection), then go to sleep in BD (with her own name on that list) But she was cleared through Finola's List so we just assumed she was new (bronze 1 skill) and moved on.
Also the amount of times you encounter a griefer is far and few, most often your problems will be with inactives. (But they hurt the game the same way )

This is just not how it works.

To put it somewhat simple:
1. Report is filed
(1.b in cases of serious griefing message the mods after filing your report so steps 2. and 3. can be skipped)
2. Ship ends
3. Several judges view and judge the report
4. Report is either cleared or sanctioned(player gets SDF points) once enough judges viewed the case
(5. Player tries to revise the sanction by messaging the mods)

I guess Dream's main problem is caused by 2., but there's a very good reason for that: Judges are players as well and viewing reports gives them information such as who the Mush is, access to PMs,...
This would give them an unfair advantage on ships.

It's also impossible to suspend the reported player until the report is filed(some ships take 2 weeks or longer). Just wouldn't work for a game, where you can die at a moment's notice.

Other alternatives have heavy drawbacks as well and require heavy coding.
For example a sanction hitting at the end of the current ship is more difficult to implement than one hitting immediately and doesn't prevent any damage the player does until then(rage quit).
On november 21, 2016
spacekadt
Dreamif the Mods know the reason for each ban and can categorize it in lets say for example 4 levels each time they give one:
lvl 1: innocent first mistake (noob ban)
lvl 2: intentional 2nd Report (didnt now noob ban)
lvl 3: occasional Reports (serioes)
lvl 4: Obvious Griefer (Dangerous)
i assume each level have SDF Points:

Without going into details, there is a certain number of points that a player must receive before quarantines kick in. All sanctions leading up to that number are warnings, of a sort. By the time a player receives quarantines, it's either a major enough offense that immediate removal from a ship is justified or the player is habitually doing things that are against the rules. It's also worth noting that the points don't fall off your record.

If you have questions about your point level or a particular sanction (though in this case, that doesn't seem to be in question), the best thing to do is to send an email to the mod inbox (too late at night for me and I'm too lazy to find the link, sorry).

i assume this means that the reason of Quarantine is irrelevant for the mods regardless how harmless/harmful the latest report is. the only thing that counts is SDF points. good to know.

[8886413]

Forcing a mush test is illegal, and suggesting to take one I think is also against the rules
However, being in a unprotected room appears mushy and that could be considered evidence against that person, but not enough on its own to consider them mush.

Either way, if you refuse a food test, they are not allowed to kill you on those grounds alone.

On november 30, 2016
Aceb
RedTigerIs tricking people into mush testing by not telling people an effect of a plant punishable? Such as not stating the fact it causes an illness (making people believe its entirely safe), and planting them to reproduce the illness causing fruit.

As long as that illness do not cause a bigger problem, it shouldn't be a problem but take into consideration (while it depends what kind of disease it spreads):

1) Someone can not like that idea, because it's actually pretty close to secretly forced mush test (when You put it like this) + You play with someone's health here + it can force someone to spend their energy in order to save themselfs / someone instead of certain action they were suppoused to do
2) Healing someone disease can take much more than eating a bad fruit, which is not very efficient
3) Much more later in the game, it can cause a bigger problem with random events (shake, etc.)
4) Even if You're gonna test people secretly like this that way, You actually might endager yourself as possible mush for poisoning crew
On november 30, 2016
[4950627]
Aceb1) Someone can not like that idea, because it's actually pretty close to secretly forced mush test (when You put it like this)

That is because that is exactly what they're doing, getting people to eat the disease causing fruit with the intent of testing them by doing so.
On november 30, 2016
[8744424]

If the player is forcing a crewmember to eat a fruit that might cause a disease you can report it since it's still a foodtest.
On november 30, 2016
Cross
RedTigerThat is because that is exactly what they're doing, getting people to eat the disease causing fruit with the intent of testing them by doing so.

It is one thing to test the mushiness of someone without their consent, which is fine (unless it is with the Natamy Rifle, that is a no-no). Even fruits that cause illness will not cause that illness 100% of the time.

It is another thing entirely to ask someone to consent to a mush-test under the penalty of death should they not cooperate with mush-testing. That is against the rules.

To put it another way, it's one thing to offer a bad fruit to someone and observe what happens if they even choose to accept your offer and eat the bad fruit. Which is fine. It's another thing to ask someone to eat two bananas in the same cycle or else we're going to kill you. Which is not fine. And just because there might be some wiggle room in the semantics of my phrasing, it's also not fine to kill someone because they didn't eat two bananas whether they were threatened or not.
On november 30, 2016
Aceb
RedTigerThat is because that is exactly what they're doing, getting people to eat the disease causing fruit with the intent of testing them by doing so.

That's not exactly mush test, because it doesn't have 100% chance like double-eating. It's close to being one.
On november 30, 2016
[4950627]
AcebThat's not exactly mush test, because it doesn't have 100% chance like double-eating. It's close to being one.

Its a fruit with a 100% chance of causing something.
On december 1, 2016
spacekadt

If you're being cunning and giving the player an option that is not required for them to accept and the player takes it, there is no forced mush test.

Mush tests on the whole are frowned upon by most of the community, but only forced mush tests are against the rules.

On december 1, 2016
[8744424]

Aceb, I wasnt judging your advice here. The comment about personal opinion was referring to all the I care/dont care about this, to I dont find his rule being fair, to I dont even know for sure what this rule means but I think this is what you should do kind of messages since this thread is not meant for such kind of chatter and I honestly dont understand why people should waste their time going through them and have troubles with finding answers theyre looking for.


Also, I dont recall mods comments on the matter being anyhow like what youre saying (I think youre referring to reports about inactivity, claiming it to be xp-farming). Judges are supposed to look into the evidence regardless of the report message theres no such thing as in case it says xp-farming clear ASAP. However, the more accurate the report message is the easier it is to find certain evidence (theres usually really a lot data to go through, guys) or understand what the reporter was pointing at to start with since its not always possible to find out what went wrong on the ship if the message isnt informative.


To add to Aceb's advice here, Id suggest pointing out what the player did wrong, so judges could check that out and see if that should be sanctioned. Report their actions instead of classifying those actions judges are capable of doing that themselves Like, griefing, playing against team, xp farming, etc. Tell what the player did wrong instead and judges will decide if it was the said griefing, playing against ones team and xp-farming.
If you dont have anything specific to point at in the players behavior, that is actually harmful - it likely means that theres no ground for reporting them (eg, you dislike the person or jump to conclusions without any facts proving them).
On december 1, 2016
spacekadt

*sighs heavily*

If there's a legitimate basis to believe that someone joined a ship only to farm XP, report them. The example given a few posts ago is about the only good example.

If someone joins, goes inactive and dies, that's probably not XP farming. But someone that does the bare minimum to keep themselves alive and nothing else, that's worth taking a look at.

What we don't particularly care for is someone repeatedly reporting every inactive or near-inactive player they come across for XP farming when there's no real reason to believe they're farming instead of some newbie that just didn't care for the game.

[9500388]

i highly doubt i'm the first one with this question but does neutral play apply to chun pre-selection?
On december 7, 2016
Lauxnos

It applies to everyone.
On december 8, 2016
spacekadt

To expand on that answer (it's true, though!) - it applies equally to Chun because the point of the rule is to give everyone (including mush) a fighting chance. If Chun is already holding knife, armor and a blaster (for instance), that severely hampers the mush team from being able to use those items.
On december 17, 2016
roobee

Are you allowed to role-play so much that it interferes with your gameplay?

For example, when your morale get's low and you get the depressed status can you purposely stop helping relays claiming you are too depressed to work on Neron/research/etc.?

Or can you refuse to tell a confirmed human Janice your exact morale, instead saying things like I am "very depressed" or "moderately sad", leaving her to guess how much to comfort you when you know that hurts the ship by making her waste her AP?
On december 17, 2016
Peanutz
Mais pourquoi est-il aussi mchant ?

Roleplay should not harm the ship in any way. It can be allowed to affect your gameplay, but only as long as it doesn't impact the ship and the survival of the crew. For instance, a pilot cannot refuse to kill hunters if the ship is in danger. As you say yourself, not telling Janice your exact morale might make her use too much AP. That is also detrimental to the crew, especially on long ships where every AP count. You can easily RP your character's morale and add an OOC comment with the exact number.

Besides, it gives people a very bad example. It is very tiring to have crewmembers just say "I am injured" or "I need morale" without saying how much exactly, no matter how many times you ask them to be more precise. In the long run, it is really harmful, because either you use too much AP on heals and comforting, or you don't spend enough and people end up dying. It's already difficult enough to get your crew to understand that without giving the bad example on purpose.
On december 17, 2016
sperbi

I want to add something though. I personally don't see the need to tell anyone in early days (while mushes alive) your exact health and morale though. So if I say i need 2 healings or plz comfort me twice to feel better, that is sufficient and is not affecting crew survival, isn' t it?
Eventually you are in danger to tell a mush your exact morale problems too.
Maybe leaving some possibilities available against metagaming is a good thing. What do you think?

havi

Sincerely, Gioele Rinaldo, owner of Rinaldo Industries

On december 18, 2016
Aceb
roobee

Are you allowed to role-play so much that it interferes with your gameplay?

For example, when your morale get's low and you get the depressed status can you purposely stop helping relays claiming you are too depressed to work on Neron/research/etc.?

Or can you refuse to tell a confirmed human Janice your exact morale, instead saying things like I am "very depressed" or "moderately sad", leaving her to guess how much to comfort you when you know that hurts the ship by making her waste her AP?

You can argue at this point even if this just role-play or straight refusing to play.

Roleplay is mostly or only text-done. You can support your actions with role-play (Derek was so happy to be able to help with research!) but You cannot support role-play with your actions (Terrence was so sad, that they did not want to help with research, despite being well rested...)

Also, there was once a player who took role-play so far, that he killed another player for "role-play" purpouses on free-mush ship. I don't have to tell You, that people didn't like that and the guilty player was trying to justify it by role-play only.

I hope everyone will get the idea.
On december 18, 2016
Crovax

Right now I got ship with several people making bad choices, rather anti-their-team choices (I don't believe we got 5 mushes already after early 1 Alpha dead), and when you ask them why they do/don't what they should, they just smirk and play "funny guys", sometimes straightly ignoring the threat of infection etc. Yeah, its somehow fun, and somehow original - but it harms the gameplay a lot at the same time when you try to figure out right who's who on the ship. Well, at least they gathered oxygen before we suffocated.
On december 19, 2016
roobee
AcebRoleplay is mostly or only text-done.

Well...different people have different definitions. For me roleplay feels fake and unsatisfying if I can't support it with actions.

But regardless of that, as the rules are that you can not let your roleplay hurt your team, I shall obey that.
On december 19, 2016
Aceb
roobee

Well...different people have different definitions. For me roleplay feels fake and unsatisfying if I can't support it with actions.

But regardless of that, as the rules are that you can not let your roleplay hurt your team, I shall obey that.

Roleplay has only one definition. The rest is game rules. Don't get me wrong, I love roleplay, but You have to know how to do it properly with rules not being broken. I remember on one ship Derek and Stephen punching themselfs in the name of getting Janice (was hilarious btw), it was just 1 punch trade, on day change, before expedition, so no one was harmed, guys performed beautiful show with RP, using only 2 punch actions with no harm and doing 95% other stuff via - text. It's even better if You let your imagination make the stuff instead of doing it via game.

Secondly, if rules would allow such more RP (like RP depression, etc.), then people would try to find loopholes, allowing negative actions or very harmful RP.


Basically the better roleplayers, the better RP, the better stuff You can create and later share it in [AP] thread! You have enough freedom and space, to perform such actions, while not hitting the rules.

Not gonna talk anymore about this here, if anyone wanna discuss, make a thread and lets go there.
On december 23, 2016
havi

So we have this problem in my ship. We know who is the last mush in the ship (Andie) but since we don't want to kill our only diplomat, we told her to choose whether she could start working in the serum (because she is also our only biologist) or get killed on the spot. In the case she decides to go for the serum, is it reportable?
On december 23, 2016
Peanutz
Mais pourquoi est-il aussi mchant ?

Of course it is. Mush are not supposed to collaborate with humans and to let themselves be cured.
On december 23, 2016
havi

Even if their only other choice is to get killed? I mean, she could always do some deviant things like destroying the cure once it's done or something like that
On december 23, 2016
[6826491]

For the humans to even make that demand can fall under incitation to spoil the game, a reportable offense in itself. You're effectively telling the Mush to stop playing for their team and surrender.
On december 23, 2016
Peanutz
Mais pourquoi est-il aussi mchant ?

I was about to edit my message. Working on the serum is not reportable in itself, as the mush can destroy it or pretend to "cure" a mush while in fact taking Anonymush. But allowing humans to cure them is reportable.

It's not the place to debate about strategies, but getting killed is not her only other choice. That's your choice. You can either kill her or try to cure her. But she has other options, she doesn't have to be killed or cured without trying to defend herself.
On december 23, 2016
havi

Ok, thanks

On december 23, 2016
[6826491]
DarjusNever offer mush to partake in serum

Not under ANY circumstances. To even make the offer can net you a sanction, under incitation to spoil the game.

Mush can just lie to you straight telling that they want to be cured No, they absolutely cannot do that, ever. To even make that suggestion is reportable as a surrender.

No player should ever consider either of these as options, because they're clear rule violations.

sperbi

I guess as mush trying to buy yourself time is in some special circumatances fine, if you are outed somehow and have no other choice than being killed, but you just try to convince humans to not kill yourself immediately because of this or that logical reason (In most cases humans would just be fools to believe that though, the mush would and has always to play for their team). On december 23, 2016
[6826491]
DarjusThat was years ago but still i don't see much harm into that if is part of the mush hunt and its unclear which player is mush...

The harm is that it's forbidden to even suggest that you desire a surrender. Surrender is explicitly forbidden, and it's not a valid tactic to hint that you'd be willing to break the rules, and y'know, surrender.

Even if humans know that you are mush and you need a little more time to get plan into action ?Absolutely not. It's not a valid tactic, and that's not up for negotiation or exceptions. A Mush cannot even hint that they wish to be converted, much less explicitly state it. Likewise, it's equally forbidden for a human to suggest that the Mush should convert them.

The circumstances are irrelevant; offering to surrender is a rule violation. It's explicitly playing against your team.

I guess as mush trying to buy yourself time is in some special circumatances fine,Not by offering to be cured. You can stall and resist in other ways.

Soroosh

It's a pretty common strategy. When you become mush, you become far more careful on how you do stuff. You won't go eat bluntly out of nowhere, you just don't step in everyroom without being worried about having people thirsty for your blood. (cus most humans tend to do food test after they have been suspected) That way you play more humanly.

The problem is, sometimes, mush forget when they need to deal the damage. Like my last game I was Frieda, and kinda saved the ship by finding an O2 planet. Simply because I had plans to convert people or use it as a chance to rampage when everyone are busy. I rampaged and converted couple of people ending the ship. So I played so much like a human yet knew when to rampage. Some people due to some reasons, just play human and never do a damage and finally die by number of proven humans.

Not to mention the fact that if you were to do that without them being exposed the question the crew should ask then is how did you know they were Mush?

In strict rule compliance it falls directly under "playing against your team".

---

Killing blitz converted Mush however is different, because for all intents and purposes they were a human, and therefore not a member of your team.
On january 11, 2017
Aceb
Dreami was told that mush can kill the other alpha mush or a newly converted mush to prove to humans that he/she is human, and with it do nothing else at all like zero mushy action and just sit back on the confirmed humans list and infiltrate with zero suspicion because he/she has the excuse "i killed the mush".

On january 11, 2017
Dzanek

Shortly, in Mush gameplay it's forbidden to lead the game into human win, I mean the scenario where the ship reaches Sol/Eden without Mush on board. Everything else is fine.

Longer, you can't admit to be Mush without causing human harm, you can't expose your partner once you're exposed for the purpose of getting them killed, you can't get yourself cured or any of your Mush partners (you can still work on RFS as long as you're going to avoid this scenario). You can't kill any of your Mush partners once you're exposed (you can still attack them if you make sure it doesn't get them killed, for the purpose of keeping them covered), you can't attack your partner once you're both exposed, you can't kill your Mush partner if they're doing well as Mush, and as long as they don't break any of these above rules you can't kill them if you don't gain human's trust for it. Also you can't mimic human when you're aware that you're about to get killed, mostly when investigators found all other humans confirmed where you stay in position which you can't be human in their eyes. You can't leave human team without Mush with access to Sol.

And remember that the intention important, not the effect. You won't be sanctioned if you caused human win by mistake when you clearly intended to win as Mush on the ship you were in. It's a game, where you can't be sure of Mush win when human also plays for their win. But remember that surrender is never an option.
On january 11, 2017
sperbi

Well said, Dzanek!

On january 12, 2017
Aceb
haviNever been in this situation, kinda new still, but i have curiosity about this
If you were a mush, and got cured, are you allowed to say who are the other mushes?

Generally, You can do two things on EN server.

1. Denounce all of your ex-comrades. You team changed and so, goals. Your sworn brothers are You mortal enemy. Get rid of them ASAP with your new comrades. [Most common and best option.]

2. Play TOTAL AMNESIA. You don't reveal anything and just play amnesiac. You can't use in anyway your knowledge to get mush again. [barely anyone decide to do that]
edit: and you can't help mush in any way, they're still your enemies and You have to get rid of them.
On january 12, 2017

Generally, You can do two things on EN server.

2. Play TOTAL AMNESIA. You don't reveal anything and just play amnesiac. You can't use in anyway your knowledge to get mush again. [barely anyone decide to do that]
edit: and you can't help mush in any way, they're still your enemies and You have to get rid of them.

On january 13, 2017
TeufelsAdvokat
roobeeSo D2 rebel base is just glory. Which means it doesn't help the human side. So is it sanctionable for Paola to decode D2 rebel base when she could have spent her AP on something else like Neron updates? If not, does that mean getting glory is a valid goal for humans? If so, are you allowed to spend all your AP on solving the Cube and doing glory researchers and nothing else?

Well, fact is that this game has a competitive aspect in form of glory. You can compete with the rest of the ship(Supernova) and/or tho whole server(glory ranking).
Not to mention some of these give distinctions too(like do a certain amount of research or the Comms thingy...). Some people like to collect those.

Glory and distinctions exist and it's ok to play for them as long as it doesn't interfere with the survival of the ship too much(doing D2 base or glory research doesn't outright kill the ship) or is done because of bad intentions(like solving the Kube to increase difficulty). For everything else there is usually some leeway.

On january 13, 2017
Aceb
roobeeSo D2 rebel base is just glory. Which means it doesn't help the human side. So is it sanctionable for Paola to decode D2 rebel base when she could have spent her AP on something else like Neron updates? If not, does that mean getting glory is a valid goal for humans? If so, are you allowed to spend all your AP on solving the Cube and doing glory researchers and nothing else?

You're going wrong way. Why would be something in the game like this sanctionable? There are hard try players who try to achieve 100% job done on their side and so, it is most possible as Paola. It is a base like any else, just is not so beneficial to human team (AND IT IS ONLY BENEFICIAL FOR HUMAN TEAM [glory])

Because most players if not everyone do not care about that stuff, it is mostly ignored.

Cube is personal gain only + You have only 10% each try. It is waste of your AP and giving your team actually a reason to get rid of You, as You do not help and make game only more difficult (AP spend).

Glory research are the same stuff as Paola base. They can be done if someone want to achieve 100% research done BUT, if You will do glory research before doing most important ones, You might be considered a mush that tries to avoiding working on proper research. It is just basically stuff to do after there's nothing else important to do.

Doing cube only is sanctionable.
Doing glory base as Paola is either self-achievement thing or something You could start suspecting comm officer (but it is not even close to justify anything in case of aggresive action).
Doing research glory is acceptable if all other research is done, mostly, after mush hunt and nexus projects are done and You're still not getting that much random events that You can afford wasting some AP.
On january 13, 2017
roobee

Wait, so you can't even cube after the mush hunt and nexus? What is the point of it existing in the game then?
On january 13, 2017
Cross

He said doing cube only is sanctionable.

There's a few times I can think of where nobody should even bat an eye at you for using the cube. 1) If the crew has determined when they're returning to Sol or Eden, then who really gives a crap if you kube away your extra AP if nothing else needs doing?

2) Once I was on a casting ship where progress on projects was halted so Paola could do upgrades, research was done, there were no more mush, and there were only so many space capsules to open and add to our mountain of scrap. Funny thing was, on that casting solving the kube allegedly gives negative glory.

These aren't the only times you can use the kube by any means. The kube is not in the game solely to get people in trouble for using it. It is not black and white. The important thing is not to be excessive, detrimental, or malicious in your use of the kube.
On january 13, 2017
TeufelsAdvokat
Cross2) Once I was on a casting ship where progress on projects was halted so Paola could do upgrades, research was done, there were no more mush, and there were only so many space capsules to open and add to our mountain of scrap. Funny thing was, on that casting solving the kube allegedly gives negative glory.

It still increases the difficulty.
In those cases where nothing has to be done(no research/projects possible, no hunters/scrap, no scanning needed, no heals needed,...), it's just better to do nothing. The overspilling AP aren't "wasted", but actually help to survive longer than when they'd be used for unnecessary actions.
The first case is a valid (and somewhat common) use and others could exist.

CrossThese aren't the only times you can use the kube by any means. The kube is not in the game solely to get people in trouble for using it. It is not black and white. The important thing is not to be excessive, detrimental, or malicious in your use of the kube.

Should at least mention the patently obvious case when the excessive, detrimental or malicious use of the Kube is allowed: Being a Mush.

I think I remember hearing about an annoying and careless Derek (he did things like idle in Raluca's room) being killed right before the crew returned to Sol, although a different situation than your Jin Su (Since nobody liked Derek on that ship). My point is: If most the other crew agree with the issue, it's usually justified.

[8281990]

It would depend. If the Jin Su is trying his best to be useful when he is around, you could set up a Commander thread for him to favorite, which he can easily refer to and find out exactly what he needs to do with his limited time (is there a planet to move to? What direction and is fuel loaded?). A couple times a day can still be workable, especially if you happen to have an IT Expert around for emergency hacking.

However, if he isn't reading chat or willing to do the best he can with his time constraints to help the ship, then there shouldn't be much problem with calling up your crewmates to discuss an assassination.

On january 23, 2017
BadBlanket

Have you attempted to speak to Jin Su about his active times and work something out? Killing someone to relieve a title is a touchy but fairly common situation (Especially for Comms officers). If you feel it's within the ships best interests to kill someone in order to relieve a title then you need to make sure you've done what you could to resolve it other ways first. Talk to him and talk to the crew. Make sure there is a trail of effort to follow in order to protect yourself and to tell us judges that you tried. Hear what he has to say then get a crew vote.

Also make sure he's as inactive as you say. If we see that he's been online for far more than you think and he just happens to have active times that are opposite to the expo teams then it might result in some disciplinary action. Don't forget that this server, while English, is played by players internationally. But if you're sure it's not an issue with time difference and it's just dangerously low activity, then it could be OK to kill him.

mbelegu

As in, idles somewhere but doesn't move from that room, just logs in to get rid of inactive or spends AP doing nothing? Surely if they are not useful we can benefit of having like one or two less hunters for our pilots?

I wouldn't say that's a good reason to waste AP and morale, especially if you have Mush aboard. If the ship is healthy, mush free, and calm then ask the crew for permission and it shouldn't be an issue. Just be sure that they are an xp farmer/inactive first. I just wouldn't recommend wasting resources on killing them, they usually end up starving regardless. If they're eating food and doing nothing with the AP then sure. Again, just make sure they're doing nothing.

Wisp

Is there a way to report someone after a ship has ended if stuff like this happens?
On february 1, 2017
Cross
WispIs there a way to report someone after a ship has ended if stuff like this happens?

You can report from the same page where you leave your last words. At this time, you can also access "My File" and view the ship's end page before leaving your last words (assuming the ship has ended). Once you publish your last words, no more reports can be filed by you for that ship.
On february 1, 2017
Wisp

Ah, thank you. I'll remember this for future ships.

On february 1, 2017
Aceb
MoscobitchYes, but once either of the mushes is human, the plan is pointless, since the new human will know what will happend, and it would be a rule violation by playing against its new human team, if he lets himself be mush again.

Yes? Totally no.

If two mushes decide to work on serum to de-mush one of them so they can re-mush them always is a no-no. Working on the serum as mush, knowing it will be used on mush and that is the only intention, is violation of rules.

Fortunately, in your example, you placed everyone on the Bridge, so Andie can speak without their walkie. If it happened elsewhere on the ship, Andie might want to try and make it to the Bridge to communicate, or find someone to whisper to.

In your example, Andie has been cured and is now on the human team. A simple way to answer these kinds of questions is ask yourself, "Would this be allowed for any other human?" In this instance, not a single human is allowed to knowingly convert themselves. Just because Andie used to not be on the human team doesn't make them any more special or afford them any exceptions to the rules when they join the human team.

spacekadt

A mush should never be curing another mush. That's playing against your own team.

If a mush lays a trap like that for JS, JS wouldn't be breaking the rules, but the mush that put him in a position of screwing over his human team or be converted could be sanctioned for incitation to spoiling.

There's almost no situation where three mush exist, one gets cured and the other two can immediately re-convert the cured mush.

[1820396]

Still, bridge. Anyone can talk freely on bridge, walkie-talkie in inventory or not. That's how bridge works.

And before you come with other examples: Humans can eat. Usually, there's some food to be found within those three rooms one AP makes you able to go. Without that one AP, most 1-2 mushes won't be able to convert you in one cycle (or day, for that matter). Cured human can wait for cycle change and try to run, as soon as they get some APs an MPs.

On the side note, your scenarios are getting quite specific. Those things usually don't happen in this kind of "perfect-stormy" way. And it's starting to look like you're just looking for loopholes.

havi

Hmmm... And what about this other case then:


Same scenario with all three mushe in the bridge, but the one who is going to be cured is jin su (by other mush of course, so that there are no humans there) and before that, walkie is dropped and shelf is trapped and also the commander's terminal is trapped. Now let's say the ship is surrounded by enough hunters to get the ship destroyed, and that for whatever reason (afk pilots, turrets and patrol ships without charges, whatever you want) the only way to save the ship is to move it (and the fuel has been charged) and that jin su has only 1 ap to moe the ship and no humans within that range of one ap to go talk to them.

What does Jin do? Do they access the terminal and convert himself? Or he does nothing and hopes for someone to go up there before cycle change?

Aside from the high potential of rule-breaking both cases are really bad gameplay. There's literally no reason to inject the serum instead of just picking Anonymush. You even got 2 Mush in the same room to testify a skill reset. Unless you have another human sitting in the room carefully watching. Although then it'd be best to convert them instead. You got 3(more likely 4, because Mushovore should have been completed as well) spores to convert your just cured Mush back. Why on earth would you do that, if you can convert another human?
Unless it's Chun sitting in the room with you carefully watching. However this would raise the question why the hell she isn't applying the serum herself.

It's possible to come up with a better plan after 5-10 minutes - not to say on the spot because that was basically the time I needed to read through all those posts. Gameplay-wise this is so horrifyingly bad, that you probably already suspected yourself it's rule-breaking. In such cases you should automatically consider and look for alternatives. Suspecting a plan may be report-/sanctionable is very often a sign for very poor play as well.

[1820396]

As announcing intention to kill suspect mush in general chat might warn those suspects or their partner, acting on own will in those matters isn't, by itself, something that is sanctionable. Killing without enough evidence or mask grief killing as mush-hunt is. If you believe he's doing one of those things, report away, judges will see a report and sanction the player, if he truly did one of those things.
On february 5, 2017
Dzanek

There's no difference if you're confirmed human to the crew or not. You're confirmed human to yourself all the time and if you suppose somebody is Mush through investigating them, you are free to kill them for legitimate reason.

The only difference is that when you're not confirmed human, you shouldn't attract suspicions on purpose merely to get yourself possibly killed. Killing a suspect doesn't include there as you might expect you'll kill the Mush.

On february 7, 2017
Cross
ZeroZiat

How do I prevent this horrible asshole from playing with us? Should I report them now and have the SDF school them? Is threatening to be this shortsighted and stuffy even reportable?

Help me prevent this ship from going sideways.

Reports are handled after the ship completes. Only in very exceptional circumstances does intervention happen before a ship completes. Generally someone's choice of skills is not a violation of the rules unless the expressed intent is to make the game more difficult or challenging for their team. As it's not a violation of the rules (with exception as above), it would reasonably follow that that reason alone is not justification enough to kill someone.

If either party feels a rule was violated, they're welcome to report it. If anyone feels they're being harassed, they're welcome to report it. The SDF is not in the business of ignoring any reports.

As for whether it's reportable to be shortsighted and stuffy? It can be. More specifically, there's not going to be much harm in filing a report. Can't really say if a violation happened without all the information included in a report. But perhaps if he calms down or he turns out to be all bark and no bite, everybody could find a way to make up and move on.
On february 7, 2017
BadBlanket

Cross is absolutely correct. Since there are clear threats and intent to kill the victimized party based on their skill selection, any action (without any other evidence) taken to kill the victim after selection would likely be met with action by the SDF after the ship is over. I would likely give points in such a circumstance and that person would be surprised by how little we ignore.

As Cross said, unless there is intent to deliberately harm the game with their skill selection, it is the player's choice to choose what skills they want to use.
On february 7, 2017
ZeroZiat

They seem to have calmed down now. Told them I hope they have something more than "He picked a skill I don't like" during accusation time. We'll see how they act after mush selection.

Thanks.
On february 12, 2017
Evalcat

What exactly is considered a forced food test? Is it considered forced if someone says "I suggest you confirm yourself or you might get killed"?
On february 12, 2017
TeufelsAdvokat

"Forced" means basically "do a food test or I'll kill you on refusal". There's usually little to no other evidence justifying the kill.

There are instances, when it's ok to offer a food test as a possibility to clear themselves. In those cases, it's basically "I'll kill you unless you give me proof of your humanity". This makes sense, if the player is already openly discussed as Mush for example. The obvious downside is, that you alarm the Mush and/or give them time to prepare some sort of rampage.
On february 12, 2017
Aceb

Forced food test in simple words is if You directly try to force someone to double eat (or eat something that causes sickness)

and / or

You use the fact or "refusal" as a "solid proof" (it is none) and based solely on this, kill is not justified.
On february 12, 2017
Cross
Aceb

Forced food test in simple words is if You directly try to force someone to double eat (or eat something that causes sickness)

and / or

You use the fact or "refusal" as a "solid proof" (it is none) and based solely on this, kill is not justified.

I take issue with the wording here, though I am sure you are meaning to say it properly: You can ask someone to double-eat. You can ask someone to eat something that causes sickness. You can try to trick somebody into doing either of the above without their consent. You cannot kill someone solely for the reason that they said, "No thank you," when you asked, or they did not fall for your tricks.

On february 15, 2017
Cross
NGJoni want to check if this is reportable
...

The way you describe it, he hasn't really done anything questionable beyond making himself look silly for accusing a confirmed human. His words here aren't objectionable in respect to the rules. His actions thus far haven't been objectionable in respect to the rules. To condemn him now would be akin to condemning a thought crime. If he actually goes and starts killing confirmed humans for the sole reason that he forgot to install cameras, then you might have a case for a report.

I suggest you approach the situation with communication, and stress that communication and planning leads to better outcomes than hasty, ill-informed actions.

Edited to add: Some people roleplay the paranoid aspect of Gioele in a way that makes them appear to be off-the-wall crazy, even though their actions are respectable. This could possibly be the case here.
